现在不是在伦敦市中心开酒吧的好时机。当迈克尔·贝尔本和他的生意 合伙人接管了法灵顿路的鹰号，当时英国正处于经济衰退之中。他们没有被吓倒，从汽车后备箱销售处购买了不匹配的陶器，拆除了水果机和飞镖盘，安装了开放式厨房和黑板菜单。该酒吧于 1991 年 1 月重新开业。

此后的几十年里，被誉为英国第一家“美食酒吧”的 Eagle 的奋斗和成功已经成为伦敦本身的缩影。起初，它的地中海菜肴很新颖；但随着这座城市的口味和人口多样化，其精致但价格实惠的食物配方被广泛模仿。 2007-09 年的金融危机并未让老鹰队感到不安。它克服了covid-19及其破坏性的社会疏远规则。贝尔本表示，对于一个一直雇用欧洲移民的场所来说，英国脱欧可能是“一个可怕的问题”。但尚未。

“我们的恢复能力如此惊人，”他总结道。伦敦也是如此。 20世纪90年代初，这座看似走下坡路的城市焕发了活力。自第二次世界大战以来，人口减少了五分之一以上，之后开始增长。富有进取心的外国人涌入。在金融放松管制、欧洲一体化和共产主义崩溃的推动下，经济蓬勃发展。到 2012 年举办奥运会时，伦敦已经名副其实地成为世界首都。

这预示着一场完美的灾难风暴，威胁着整个城市，尤其是伦敦的倾覆。它的商业之心已经受到金融危机的冲击。然后，一个以移民为基础的国际大都市面临着英国脱欧的关闭，而新冠病毒大流行则禁止游客进入这个地球上访问量最大的地方之一。

然而，就像老鹰一样，伦敦正在蓬勃发展——这种坚韧精神值得世界各地的城市借鉴。其全球化经济经受住了英国脱欧的考验，远好于末日论者的预测。尽管在移民问题上有各种政治上的咆哮，但它仍然吸引着雄心勃勃的新移民。而且它比许多城市更有能力承受新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 造成的干扰。从南到北、从西到东穿越伦敦，你会发现它最大的挑战是其活力的结果，而不是衰退。从伦敦南部佩卡姆附近开始。

一位身着约鲁巴礼仪服装的富丽堂皇的女士骑着马走在佩卡姆的大街上。打篮球的年轻人和西非杂货店的购物者惊奇地看着（带着典型的伦敦漫不经心的态度，有些人连眼皮都不眨一下）。阿德耶米·迈克尔 (Adeyemi Michael) 的短片最近在佩卡姆 (Peckham) 的南伦敦画廊 (South London Gallery) 展出，向 20 世纪 70 年代开始涌入首都这一地区的尼日利亚人致敬，该地区因此赢得了“小拉各斯”的绰号。

南部十字路口

您仍然可以在 Lolak Afrique 咖啡馆品尝美味的 jollof 米饭，这家咖啡馆位于佩卡姆的主要街道附近。但这个街区以及伦敦的尼日利亚社区正在发生变化。随着鸡尾酒吧和寿司店的入驻，尼日利亚人已经分散开来，他们的人数在包括佩卡姆在内的萨瑟克区下降，而在其他地方则有所上升。伦敦从来没有像一些美国城市那样存在种族隔离。贝尔法斯特女王大学的杰玛·卡特尼 (Gemma Catney) 的分析表明，在过去几十年里，这种情况逐渐变得不那么严重，非洲黑人人口的分散速度尤其快。

随着它的蔓延，伦敦的尼日利亚人口也在不断增长。在过去的几年里，英国脱欧后的移民政策接纳了更多来自欧洲以外的学生和工人（主要是医疗保健领域）。截至 2023 年 6 月的一年中，有 141,000 名尼日利亚人移居英国，超过整个欧盟的总人数，而欧盟目前有净移民。

12月4日，政府宣布了削减移民的计划。但至少到目前为止，人们对英国脱欧可能阻止移民涌入伦敦的担忧尚未成为现实。英国脱欧的讽刺之一是，其他移民的到来足以弥补欧洲人的短缺。部分原因是，伦敦人口在疫情期间有所下降，目前已增加至 900 万，预计到 2040 年将达到 1000 万。伦敦国王学院的乔纳森·波特斯 (Jonathan Portes) 表示，考虑到技能和学生的流入，英国脱欧对这座城市的影响“至少在移民方面是积极的”。正如本杰明·迪斯雷利 (Benjamin Disraeli) 在 1870 年所写，它仍然是“每只鸟儿的栖息地”。

最近涌入这个已经非常多元化的城市似乎也没有激起太大的紧张气氛。民意调查机构益普索 (Ipsos) 表示，认为移民对其家乡产生积极影响的伦敦人是巴黎人的两倍多。两次被迫担任保守党政府内政大臣的苏埃拉·布雷弗曼(Suella Braverman)最近声称多元文化主义已经“失败”。她就是相反的例子：她是一名佛教徒，由来自毛里求斯和肯尼亚的父母在伦敦长大，她找到了一位犹太丈夫，并晋升到该国最高职位之一。你可以称之为伦敦梦。

以另一种广泛预测的方式，英国脱欧确实给伦敦造成了重创：损害了这座已经受到金融危机和其他中心崛起困扰的增长引擎。然而，与老鹰一样，到目前为止，后果是可以控制的。

英国脱欧的总体成本对于那些没有发生的事情（实习机会被放弃、爱情永远不会开花）和那些发生的事情都会产生同样的影响。智库新金融的威廉·赖特 (William Wright) 表示，它对伦敦金融城的影响也是如此。他指出，美国投资银行在巴黎创造了数百个新就业岗位，在不同的情况下，这些就业岗位可能会转移到伦敦。至于已经发生的事情：伦敦新上市股票以及欧洲股票和衍生品交易的份额已经下降。

尽管如此，由于英国脱欧，伦敦金融城的现有工作岗位相对较少。咨询公司安永的最新估计约为7000人，远低于一度预期的数万人。赖特先生预测，伦敦金融城将不再是欧洲默认的金融中心；但由于其在全球金融市场的地位，它仍将是欧洲的主导中心。它足够大，可以应对。

除了规模庞大之外，伦敦金融城和伦敦其他地区在英国脱欧后还享有另外两个优势。首先，他们已经与欧洲以外的世界开展了大量业务，特别是从美国获得了大量的外国直接投资（ FDI ）。伦敦经济学院 ( LSE ) 的里卡多·克雷森齐 (Riccardo Crescenzi) 表示，自英国脱欧以来，伦敦变得更加依赖美国投资。令人担忧的是，如果将裁员和撤资考虑在内，2021 年伦敦和英国将出现自 1984 年以来首次外国资本净流出。克雷森齐教授表示，即便如此，伦敦仍然是欧洲新FDI项目最多的城市。

另一个好处是，伦敦的专业行业——不仅是金融，还有法律、会计、咨询、媒体和高等教育——与其他行业相比，受到英国脱欧后规则的阻碍较少。另一家智库决议基金会的艾米丽·弗莱 (Emily Fry) 指出，2016 年至 2021 年间，伦敦的服务出口增长了 47%；英国其他地区的增幅仅为 4%。进口零部件和出口货物的地方遭受了更多与英国脱欧相关的成本和官僚主义。

科技大师兼投资者布伦特·霍伯曼 (Brent Hoberman) 坚称，科技领域的势头尤其强劲，无法“停止前进”。由于英国脱欧，“我们必须对竞争更加偏执”，但他认为，伦敦仍然是在欧洲创办科技公司的最佳地点。美国风险投资家仍然热衷于此。这一记录支持了他的信心：伦敦产生的科技独角兽数量比其三个最接近的欧洲竞争对手——柏林、巴黎和斯德哥尔摩——的总和还要多。

畅通无阻的枢纽

邻近的顶尖大学以及丰富的技能和资本强化了其长久以来的优点——时区、英语和法治。总部位于伦敦的金融科技公司 Kuda 的创始人 Babs Ogundeyi 表示，精明的当地天使投资者帮助吸引了更多资本。库达在尼日利亚经营一家纯数字银行，并在英国为非洲人提供汇款服务。奥贡德伊指出，尽管英国脱欧带来了诸多麻烦，但它却导致了与非洲的更紧密联系。

结果是英国脱欧的另一个讽刺。你也可以称之为业力或诗意的正义。伦敦是英格兰唯一在 2016 年公投中投票决定留在欧盟的地区，其表现比那些想要脱欧的地区要好。由于重叠的原因，它从大流行中恢复得更快。前往北伦敦看看原因。

莎莉·诺斯

在阿森纳足球场的一个寒冷的夜晚，俱乐部的新国歌在地面上响起：“永远的北伦敦/无论天气如何/这些街道是我们自己的。”这是一首伤感但感人的曲调，尤其是在封锁几个月、观众被禁止观看之后。现在体育场挤满了人；球队的吉祥物枪手龙正在与年轻球迷击掌。球迷们对他们的英雄边锋布卡约·萨卡（他及时进球）的铲球感到非常愤怒。

就像 Eagle 的狂欢一样，伦敦的娱乐经济在经历了新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 的低迷之后再次活跃起来。其七家英超足球俱乐部在全球范围内展现软实力。在美国游客增加的推动下，旅游业几乎恢复到大流行前的水平。伦敦剧院协会表示观众人数已经增加。在某些周末，地铁比 2019 年更繁忙。

总而言之，伦敦灵活的经济复苏比该国其他地区强劲得多。与其他城市一样，它在后疫情时代也面临着障碍。但它比许多人都为他们配备了更好的装备。

一些零售区已经面临网上购物的压力，举步维艰，尤其是牛津街，今年在圣诞灯光下显得有些脏乱。随着露宿者数量的增加，空置的商店也造成了伦敦市中心部分地区的破旧空气。然而，据一些人称，其活力的主要威胁是伦敦人不愿重返办公室全职工作。

One Triton Square 是一座办公楼，距 Eagle 一英里，位于摄政公园附近，是这一趋势的象征。它坐落在一个时髦的开发项目中，拥有现代办公大楼的所有时尚附属设施，包括攀岩墙和艺术画廊。但大楼是空的。黑暗的中庭里，灯光诡异地闪烁；自动扶梯被冻住了。今年早些时候，Facebook 的母公司 Meta 支付了巨额费用，在塔楼搬入之前就取消了租约。

这座幽灵般的建筑并不是独一无二的。伦敦市中心商业地产的空置率很高，部分原因是——与其他地方一样，而且更是如此——人们不愿意改掉在大流行期间养成的在家工作（ WFH ）的习惯。智库城市中心最近的一项调查发现，伦敦市中心的员工平均每周在办公室工作 2.3 天，少于其他英国人。斯坦福大学的尼克·布鲁姆 (Nick Bloom) 对 32 个国家进行了调查研究，其中英国工人呆在家里的时间比加拿大人还要多。总而言之，这些发现意味着伦敦人是世界上缺勤率最高的工人之一。

面对面的互动有利于提高生产力，而在疫情爆发之前，伦敦就已经陷入停滞状态。办公室出席率低可能会最终吓退外国投资者。不过，在居家办公的未来，伦敦拥有其他地方所缺乏的吸引力。

每周工作三天的办公室必须与过去的办公室有所不同：更灵活、更有吸引力。然而，网络、交通和娱乐的可能性意味着保留伦敦市中心总部的理由比设立卫星办公室的理由更充分。值得注意的是，在家办公文化并没有导致伦敦人大军撤退到工作场所之外。大多数在 2021 年至 2022 年夏季搬回家的伦敦内城区人都在城市周围流动， 而不是逃避它。

它摆脱了另一场一些人认为会令其高贵的危机：乌克兰战争和随后对俄罗斯精英的制裁，俄罗斯精英曾给伦敦的诽谤律师、房地产经纪人、公关公司和足球迷带来欢乐。 《世界管家》一书的作者奥利弗·布洛（Oliver Bullough）表示，尽管他们声名狼藉、浮夸华丽，但他们的慷慨总是不如中国和中东的慷慨重要，该书揭露了英国为盗贼统治提供服务的情况。无论如何，许多其他豪赌客仍然以伦敦为家，或者其中之一。 （要参观一座反映伦敦寡头纵容的奥兹曼德纪念碑，可以从哈罗德百货公司向西漫步，寻找一个废弃的地铁站。2014 年，政府以 5300 万英镑（当时为 8700 万美元）的价格将其卖给了美国通缉的乌克兰大亨德米特里·菲尔塔什 (Dmitry Firtash)。涉嫌腐败的指控，但他否认了。）

毕竟，伦敦在其 2000 年的历史中经历了各种各样的冲击。伦敦政治经济学院的托尼·特拉弗斯认为，它最不稳定的时期是在公元五世纪罗马人离开之后。 1340 年代，黑死病杀死了大部分人口； 1666 年的大火将其大片地区夷为平地。一座适应了港口衰落的港口城市，也是一座适应了帝国衰落的帝都。它反抗了 1940-41 年的闪电战——当时，大多数伦敦人并没有像都市传说中那样躲在地铁里，而是直接睡在家里。

这种冷静是伦敦持久的特征之一。它现在最担心的可能不是外部威胁，而是成功的后果。莫斯科、巴黎、首尔、东京：其他城市主导着本国的政治和经济。即便如此，伦敦因其对政府、金融、媒体和艺术的控制而脱颖而出（这两个世界在老鹰大厦发生碰撞，这里是金融家和媒体类型的酒吧，也是艺术画廊的所在地）。同样明显的是伦敦人和他们的同胞在人口结构和观点上的差异。

根据最新统计，伦敦的人均可支配家庭收入比全国高出 43%。伦敦人更年轻、更左翼、更多元化：少数族裔占居民的 46%，是英格兰和威尔士这一比例的两倍多。五分之二的伦敦人出生在国外。与伦敦在各郡享有的“现代蛾摩拉”的名声相反，伦敦平均而言比其他地区在社会上更加保守，也较少酗酒。

为此，要感谢它的移民，其中许多人都是虔诚的信徒。他们还帮助提高了伦敦学校的标准，本世纪伦敦学校已经从英国地区表现最差的学校变成了最好的学校。要近距离观察这种现象，请向西走。

索撒尔西郊被称为“小印度”，旁遮普和阿富汗餐馆、清真寺和锡克教寺庙遍布。当地费瑟斯通高中 (Featherstone High School) 校长内森·沃尔特斯 (Nathan Walters) 表示，该校 85% 的学生在家里使用另一种语言。近三分之一的人获得免费校餐（衡量贫困的标准）。无论父母自己是否会说英语，他们对教育都“始终持积极态度”。结果远远超出全国平均水平。沃尔特斯先生表示，接近机会就是一种动力。学生们“几乎可以从卧室的窗户看到它”。

几个世纪以来，伦敦的主导地位以及对人才和资本的贪婪一直令人担忧。 400 多年前，詹姆斯一世国王抱怨道：“很快，伦敦将成为整个英格兰。”在 19 世纪，它被称为“大文”（囊肿）。最近的民意调查发现，其他英国人认为这里拥挤且昂贵，而居民则傲慢而孤立。许多人认为它受到政策制定者和财政部门的青睐，尽管它的贡献远远超过其回报。伦敦的人均净财政贡献超过 4,000 英镑。

这种怨恨情绪助长了整个西方的民粹主义。在英国，它给英国脱欧公投增添了色彩。但自那时以来，财富、多样性和机会方面的鸿沟不断扩大（见图 1）。

为了缩小差距，现任政府和前任政府一样，重复使用了失败的想法。例如，最近的一份议会报告指出，每 10 到 15 年就会可靠地启动将公务员工作转移到偏远地区的计划。这些努力通常包括限制伦敦的增长，希望将其转移到其他地方。一个很好的例子是 1964 年的一项误导性规定（现已被废弃），该规定实际上禁止在伦敦市中心开发新的办公楼。

很多时候，政策限制了首都，却没有提振其他地方，最终惩罚了所有人。事实证明，伦敦吸引力的另一个巨大成本也同样难以解决。这凄惨的叫声从屋内传来。

“经济适用房并不总是这么好，”麦格拉斯路的一位居民用伦敦滑稽的轻描淡写的语气说道。对她来说，家是伦敦东部纽汉区斯特拉特福一个令人着迷的开发项目中的 26 栋住宅之一。这些单位（其中一些是公共住房）坐落在不漂亮的 20 世纪庄园中，看起来像一座摩尔式城堡，有塔楼和垛口，但也有欢迎的拱门、阳台和绿树成荫的中央庭院。走上铁轨，你会看到闪闪发光的塔楼，它们是奥运会刺激的复兴的一部分。

麦格拉斯路的建筑师彼得·巴伯表示，我们可以从北非和中东的紧凑型城市中学到很多东西。他回忆说，纽汉姆市议会最初期望设计一座公寓楼。相反，他效仿了乔治亚风格的露台，这种露台是伦敦高效住房的巅峰之作，但又具有独特的风格。

道路堵塞、空气污染、通勤时间长且昂贵、警察队伍信誉不佳——伦敦不可避免地患有许多大城市的弊病。与同胞相比，伦敦人的社区归属感较低；正如在喧嚣中常见的那样，生活会感到孤独和原子化。 （查尔斯·狄更斯写道：“奇怪的是，一个人可能在伦敦生活和死亡，却很少受到注意。”） 但最尖锐、最持久的问题是住房的稀缺性和成本——而这一问题在东区最为尖锐、最顽固。

定向压缩

在维多利亚时代晚期，东区被称为“饥饿的帝国”和“可怕的夜晚之城”。如今，纽汉姆的过度拥挤程度是该市的两倍，而其本身则是全国平均水平的两倍多。造成短缺的根本原因是几十年来未能提供足够的新住房，也未能像巴伯先生那样富有想象力地利用空间。

结果既不可避免又令人震惊。美国政治战略家詹姆斯·卡维尔曾开玩笑说，他希望转世成为债券市场，因为那样他就可以恐吓所有人。另一个不错的选择是回归伦敦房价：也许只有这座城市厚颜无耻的狐狸才能与它的坚不可摧相媲美。诚然，持续二十年的金融驱动的繁荣最近已经趋于平缓，但仍处于一个令人眼花缭乱的平台期。

2020 年，首都的平均房屋售价是平均收入的 13 倍以上，几乎是二十年前的两倍（见图 2）。 Eagle 附近的两居室公寓售价约为 100 万英镑。与此同时，自 1981 年以来，居住在公共住房中的伦敦人比例已从三分之一以上下降到五分之一。私营部门的租金飙升：2022 年，租金中位数为收入中位数的 35%。正如伦敦国王学院的杰克·布朗所说，这座城市“从未如此大或如此昂贵”。

所有这些都意味着伦敦人对富裕的看法是不完整的。这是一个富裕的城市，但也有很多穷人。住房成本和贫困率因素高于英格兰其他地区。住在临时住所的伦敦家庭数量是全国家庭数量的八倍。最富裕的十分之一的收入几乎是最贫困人口的十倍。由于伦敦的经济地理异常一体化，贫困家庭和富裕家庭比巴黎或纽约更加紧密地联系在一起，大街上的英镑商店毗邻手工面包店。

特拉弗斯教授指出，对伦敦拥挤程度的抱怨，回想起一个老笑话：餐馆太拥挤了，没人愿意再去那里了。尽管如此，这场大流行可能会为这个古老的问题找到解决方案。在一个写字楼供应过剩而住宅短缺的地方，在可能的情况下，将商业建筑改造成住宅建筑是有意义的。在混合工作时代，现在比以往任何时候都更需要从现有的通勤走廊开始，在“绿化带”的一些受保护土地上进行建设。

类似的事情发生在过去的危机之后。克里斯托弗·雷恩在大火的灰烬中重新构想了这座城市。理想主义的城市规划者在闪电战的废墟中再次这样做了。过去几年和过去两千年的证据表明，伦敦——世界上最伟大的城市之一，也许也是最具弹性的城市——将找到一种应对和繁荣的方法。 ■

B确实是残酷和令人痛苦的，但也许以色列和哈马斯之间的战争也可能是一个机会。至少美国总统是这么认为的。尽管他支持以色列自卫的权利，但他认为这场战斗应该给以色列人和巴勒斯坦人敲响警钟。他在接受电视采访时表示：“现在时机已经成熟，双方应该认识到，他们所走的道路不会为其人民带来繁荣和安全。”

在这个例子中，总统是大约 15 年前刚刚就职的巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama)。但今天也可能是乔·拜登。历史在中东不断重演。加沙战争再次引发和平讨论，考虑到 10 月 7 日以色列袭击加沙期间 1,200 多名以色列人遭到屠杀，以及随后约 16,000 名巴勒斯坦人被杀害，和平讨论似乎有些牵强。自 1948 年以色列建国以来，圣地从未经历过如此多的流血事件。和平似乎从未如此遥远。

阅读我们对以色列和哈马斯之间战争的所有报道。

尽管如此，拜登还是希望它能够出现。 “当这场危机结束后，必须对接下来的情况有一个愿景，我们认为这必须是两国解决方案，”他在十月份表示。 11 月在巴林举行的一次会议上，一位又一位阿拉伯官员发出了类似的信息。阿拉伯联合酋长国（ UAE ）总统顾问安瓦尔·加尔加什（Anwar Gargash）表示：“我们需要回到两国解决方案，回到以色列和巴勒斯坦并存的国家。”

一些人认为此类言论只是一块遮羞布，旨在消除人们对西方支持以色列以及阿拉伯国家在可怕的战争中无所作为的疑虑。毕竟，以色列和巴勒斯坦之间30年的和平进程充满了失败。如果至少没有三项根本性的改变，谈判的重启从一开始就注定会失败。首先是新的领导层。当前加沙战争双方的政党正是30年前竭力破坏新生和平进程的政党。他们必须走。接下来是努力让谈判变得可信：双方都更加怀疑对方的诚意。最后，双方都需要激励才能达成协议。巴勒斯坦人需要感到他们的国家是可行的，以色列人需要感到他们的国家是安全的。

两国解决方案以这样或那样的形式已经存在了近一个世纪。 1947年，联合国通过了一项巴勒斯坦分治计划，该计划将创建两个国家，一个阿拉伯国家，一个犹太国家，并由国际社会控制耶路撒冷。阿拉伯国家拒绝了，以色列宣布独立，其邻国迅速入侵。

经过数十年的冲突，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人于 1991 年在马德里举行的和平会议上开始谈判。随后于 1993 年达成奥斯陆协议，该协议规定了建立巴勒斯坦国的五年期限，同时建立了巴勒斯坦权力机构 ( PA ) ，一个类似的政府，尽管权力和管辖权有限，仅对部分被占领土进行管辖。一系列失败接踵而至：戴维营和塔巴峰会、布什政府的“和平路线图”、奥巴马的外交。上一次直接谈判于 2014 年破裂，此后再也没有恢复过。

遥不可及却又坚不可摧

一直以来，两国解决方案的轮廓几乎没有变化。加沙和约旦河西岸将建立一个巴勒斯坦国——约占历史上巴勒斯坦面积的 22%——其首都位于东耶路撒冷。以色列将在约旦河西岸保留一些定居点，以换取领土交换，并撤离其他定居点。象征性数量的难民将被允许返回以色列，更多的难民将被允许返回巴勒斯坦。

这个想法曾经很流行，但许多人失去了信心。即使在 10 月 7 日之前，也只有大约三分之一的巴勒斯坦人和以色列犹太人支持两国解决方案，低于五年前的近一半（见图表）。 “每一个失败的进程都有一个代价，”以色列政治家西蒙·佩雷斯的外交政策顾问尼姆罗德·诺维克说。 “这强化了这是不可能做到的错误结论。”自 10 月 7 日以来，以色列对任何形式的和平谈判的支持都大幅下降。

尽管幻灭，但没有明确的选择。民意调查显示，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人对于如何结束冲突存在分歧。一些人希望有一个“单一国家解决方案”，让他们生活在一个享有平等权利的国家。其他人支持种族隔离或种族清洗（当然，他们不同意这种做法的受害者是谁）。

这些都是无用的。 10 月 7 日的事件打破了现状。驱逐或歧视是令人憎恶的。一国解决方案可能听起来合理，但实际上行不通：大多数以色列人和巴勒斯坦人拒绝这个想法。

剩下两个状态。问题在于，这个解决方案需要双方做出巨大牺牲。以色列人将不得不放弃土地，而巴勒斯坦人则必须放弃自 1948 年以来失去的大部分土地。双方领导人都需要向持怀疑态度的公众兜售这些让步。但双方都没有这样的领导人。

以色列有本雅明·内塔尼亚胡，他的整个职业生涯都在努力阻止巴勒斯坦国的出现。为了讨好奥巴马，他确实在 2009 年巴伊兰大学的一次演讲中支持了两国解决方案，尽管六年后他宣称中东已经发生了变化，他的演讲“无关紧要”。他的利库德集团通过了反对巴勒斯坦建国的决议。以色列公共广播公司 Kan 在 11 月报道称，内塔尼亚胡先生会见了利库德集团的后座议员，恳求他的政治生存。他说：“战后，我是唯一能够阻止加沙、朱迪亚和撒玛利亚建立巴勒斯坦国的人。”他用的是约旦河西岸的希伯来语名称。

但内塔尼亚胡先生的日子已经屈指可数了。根据 11 月份公布的民意调查显示，大多数以色列人希望他下台——76% 的人希望他下台。调查显示，如果举行选举，他的利库德集团将失去其目前在议会 120 名议员中拥有的 32 个席位中的一半左右。

接替内塔尼亚胡先生的领跑者是前陆军参谋长本尼·甘茨 (Benny Gantz)，他于 10 月份不情愿地加入了内塔尼亚胡先生的战时内阁。他的中右翼民族团结党在民调中大幅领先。他正在成为以色列难以驾驭的政治中的一个罕见人物：一个团结的人物。

部分原因在于他对两国解决方案的模糊立场。他在公开场合对此鲜有提及。该党的官方立场是含糊其辞地呼吁“与巴勒斯坦人分离”，但没有详细说明如何实现这一目标。与甘茨关系密切的消息人士称，他无意提供更具体的信息。他们说，这样做对内塔尼亚胡先生有利。巴勒斯坦建国问题是一个棘手问题，因此甘茨先生将尽力避免这个问题，以吸引选民远离总理。

“在本尼与美国人的谈话中，他说我们应该停止在新情况下使用旧词，”一名助手说。换句话说，他愿意讨论两国解决方案的某种形式，但对使用这个不光彩的术语持谨慎态度。在该党进行的调查中，大多数以色列人赞成用“两个独立实体”等其他术语描述两国解决方案。

如果甘茨先生寻求对两国解决方案进行一些修改，他将面临政治障碍。他所在的政党包括反对这一举措的鹰派议员。 “甘茨那里有一些非常非常右翼的人，”以色列智库肖雷什研究所的丹·本·大卫说。对于他的一些潜在的联盟伙伴以及在过去几十年里转向右翼的以色列公众来说也是如此。

巴勒斯坦政治看起来更加令人生畏。对于哈马斯来说，和平进程是不可想象的，因为哈马斯花了三十年的时间来搅局。它发起了一场自杀式爆炸运动，以破坏奥斯陆协议，然后在巴勒斯坦人第二次起义或起义期间持续发动袭击，使一代以色列人对和平理念产生了不满。

巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯和他的民族主义法塔赫政党都支持两国解决方案。但他已经 88 岁了，很快将开始本应四年任期的第 20 个年头。很少有巴勒斯坦人（或以色列人）认为他有合法性或智慧来领导认真推动和平。一名以色列官员表示，“他处于一个妄想泡沫之中，周围都是三四个非常有权势的唯唯诺诺的人”，阿巴斯的许多前同事也有同样的评价。

白宫正在考虑让技术官僚前总理、国际货币基金组织前官员萨拉姆·法耶兹重返原来的工作岗位。就连阿拉伯官员现在也私下表示，他们希望改变巴勒斯坦领导层。沙特正在推动阿巴斯的得力助手侯赛因·谢赫接替总统。阿联酋希望看到前法塔赫安全负责人穆罕默德·达赫兰（Muhammad Dahlan）发挥作用，过去十年他一直流亡在阿布扎比。它们都会被以色列接受——但也许不会被巴勒斯坦人接受。民意调查显示他们的受欢迎程度只有个位数。

看似合理但不可行

另一个选择是法塔赫领导人马尔万·巴尔古提（Marwan Barghouti），他因策划袭击以色列平民而在以色列服刑五次无期徒刑。 （他拒绝进行辩护，谴责审判是非法的。）一些人希望他能成为巴勒斯坦人纳尔逊·曼德拉（Nelson Mandela），出狱后团结分裂的运动并与以色列进行谈判。他经常被评为最受欢迎的巴勒斯坦领导人，但这主要是因为他已经淡出了公众视线数十年，而当时法塔赫正陷入腐败和衰老。即使以色列允许他出境，也不清楚他的领导人能力如何。

美国和阿拉伯官员一直在推动巴勒斯坦选举。不过，至少在约旦河西岸，这可能会为哈马斯的残余势力带来胜利，巴勒斯坦人认为哈马斯是唯一愿意对抗以色列的政党。法塔赫要想重新获得民众的支持，需要做两件事。一是遏制其成员猖獗的腐败行为（当被问及巴勒斯坦权力机构要解决的最紧迫问题时，更多的巴勒斯坦人提到腐败而不是占领）。另一个是表明非暴力方法可以产生结果。 “他们必须让哈马斯变得无效，”来自加沙的巴勒斯坦学者哈利勒·萨耶说。 “人们必须看到哈马斯并没有真正做任何好事。”

这需要以色列做出让步，这就引出了第二个问题：如何让谈判变得可信。经过几十年的失败，以色列人和巴勒斯坦人都会持怀疑态度。不过，对于以色列人来说，这几十年仍然是美好的：它们恰逢经济繁荣、长期相对和平以及与阿拉伯国家关系迅速发展。对于巴勒斯坦人来说，他们带来的只是加深的绝望。 “独立巴勒斯坦国的整个计划正在成为过去的一部分，”巴勒斯坦前部长加桑·哈提卜说。以色列有责任消除这种看法。

诺维克先生是以色列安全司令部的成员，该组织由退休安全官员组成，主张两国解决方案。他提供了以色列可以采取的一系列步骤，以表明新的承诺。它可能会缩小C区，即以色列完全控制的西岸三分之二的地区，并扩大B区，巴勒斯坦权力机构在该区拥有民事事务权，但无安全权。 （巴勒斯坦权力机构完全控制的A区甚至更小：参见地图。）它可以停止拆除C区无证房屋，因为它拒绝向巴勒斯坦人发放建筑许可证（通常每年发放十个或更少）。它可以减少军队对巴勒斯坦城市的袭击。

然而，对于巴勒斯坦人来说，这些步骤还远远不够。稍微扩大B区很难成为法塔赫可以向可疑公众兜售的一项响亮成就。 “我们为了一个国家已经等待了 30 年，”一位外交官说道。 “我们不需要一些建筑许可证。”毕竟，《奥斯陆协议》因渐进主义而被毁：双方需要通过象征性举措建立信任，然后才能就更实质性的步骤达成一致。

当被问及什么才是更严肃的姿态时，几位巴勒斯坦分析人士指出了被占领的约旦河西岸的定居点，这里居住着约 465,000 名以色列人。他们说，仅仅冻结新建筑是不够的；以前曾尝试过这种做法，包括奥巴马领导下的尝试。以色列应该更进一步，拆除一些在和平协议中必须放弃的定居点。这既可以建立信心，又可以推进最终地位协议。在以色列，这在政治上似乎也是不可能的，特别是在 10 月 7 日之后，因为这将被视为奖励一场屠杀。

经过数十年的拖延，如果没有美国的压力，以色列不太可能做出任何重大姿态。 “除非以色列体系确实认为朝这个方向前进是有代价的，否则我看不出如何为不同的政治腾出一些空间，”以色列前谈判代表丹尼尔·利维(Daniel Levy)表示。一位阿拉伯外交官表示，这种压力最初也应该针对定居者：“美国需要采取强硬措施。”

12月6日，美国宣布将对袭击巴勒斯坦人及其财产的暴力定居者实施签证禁令。这是前所未有的一步，但也具有象征意义。出于意识形态动机的定居者不太可能因签证禁令而被劝退。无论如何，他们中的一些人是不能被禁止的：他们是美国公民。

美国对定居点的挤压要想取得成功，就需要将以色列也包括在内。国际法规定以色列军队有义务保护被占领土上的巴勒斯坦人，但以色列军队经常在定居者发动袭击时袖手旁观。如果继续允许（有时甚至怂恿）此类暴力，美国可能会威胁削减军事援助。对于巴勒斯坦人和阿拉伯世界来说，这将是一个明确的信号，表明美国认真地试图扮演一个不那么有偏见的角色。但在选举年，或者如果唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 在 2024 年赢得总统宝座，这样的威胁是很难想象的。不过，如果拜登获得连任，这样的举动将受到党内进步派的欢迎。

除了威胁之外，美国及其合作伙伴还必须提供激励措施。对于巴勒斯坦人来说，这些可能主要是财务方面的。最紧迫的问题是如何重建支离破碎的加沙，其费用轻而易举就达到数百亿美元。富裕的海湾国家愿意做出贡献，但前提是加沙成为巴勒斯坦国的一部分，并且它们的投资不太可能再次被炸毁。

与此同时，海湾国家可以帮助缓解以色列的安全担忧。奥斯陆进程开始时，只有一个阿拉伯国家埃及与以色列建立了外交关系。如今，其中六个已加入，而且沙特阿拉伯似乎也愿意加入该俱乐部。与阿拉伯世界建立正常关系的前景似乎是真实的，这是过去几十年从未有过的。不仅结束与巴勒斯坦人的冲突，而且结束与整个地区的冲突应该是一个强有力的诱因。

本月早些时候在卡塔尔举行的一次会议上，海湾国家讨论了战后加沙的计划。他们决心与约旦、埃及和西方大国合作，组建国际联盟，推动两国解决方案。阿拉伯国家将要求巴勒斯坦权力机构选择新的领导人，而美国将向以色列施压。

但即使海湾国家承认以色列，伊朗支持的激进组织（例如黎巴嫩真主党或也门胡塞武装）也不会这样做。 “我们必须让伊朗加入，”一位来自海湾地区的外交官表示。当被问及这是否现实时，他表示反对。几十年来，对以色列的敌意一直是伊斯兰共和国意识形态的核心原则。巴勒斯坦国的建立可能不会在一夜之间将他们变成犹太复国主义者。

熟悉但不确定

那么，风险就是历史再次重演。新一批领导人可能会口头上支持两国解决方案。以色列可能会软化对巴勒斯坦权力机构的敌意并做出一些让步。海湾国家将承诺提供资金和认可。但所提出的协议从根本上来说与以前是一样的——这一协议遭到了更为乐观的一代以色列人和巴勒斯坦人的拒绝。

近年来，双方知识分子都开始呼吁更多的创造性思维。一种想法是建立一个联盟，其中既有犹太人又有巴勒斯坦实体。一方的公民有权在另一方生活和工作。这个想法是为了降低如此小块土地如何瓜分的重要性，并让双方对对方的稳定更加感兴趣。

这个想法比标准的两国蓝图面临更多的障碍，但新颖的概念有一个优点。 “以色列受益于不严肃的国际做法，这种做法只是说，回到两国谈判，”利维先生说。这些谈判常常成为目的而不是手段，尽管到目前为止已经几乎没有什么可谈判的了：一切都已经被无休止地讨论过。过去几个月的事件表明现状是难以维持的。改变是不可避免的。唯一的问题是它将采取什么形式。 ■

尽管面临战争和制裁，11月初，经过翻修的苏联时代“国民经济成就展览”在莫斯科重新开幕。原版于 1939 年落成，就在德国和俄罗斯入侵波兰前几周，它掩盖了前几年的饥荒和恐怖。相反，展览颂扬了苏联科学的奇迹和集体化的优点；一个特殊的冰淇淋大厅向群众分发美食，一座 25 米高的斯大林雕像慷慨地俯视着下方。数百万人在独裁者与过去的“大决裂”中丧生，俄罗斯的经济和社会被彻底重塑，但这一切都被描述为纯粹的进步。

阅读我们最近对乌克兰战争的更多报道

这与今天的翻修工程有着类似的故事，一条未来派的、布满屏幕的隧道向游客展示了弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 领导下的过去 20 年的辉煌。一个庆祝俄罗斯地区的展馆以顿涅茨克、赫尔松、卢甘斯克和扎波罗热为特色，俄罗斯军队目前正试图从乌克兰夺取这四个省份。持续流血的唯一迹象是一朵由弹片碎片组成的花朵。 1945年以来欧洲最大规模战争的爆发、俄罗斯境内重新建立警察国家以及后苏联时期早期改革和西化趋势的彻底逆转都不见踪影。

这与战争初期的震惊和混乱截然不同，当时卢布暴跌，数十万人逃离该国，抗议活动震撼了俄罗斯的城市。此后，普京凭借高油价成功稳定了经济，并通过严厉镇压压制了异议。这使他能够保留精英阶层的忠诚，而精英阶层反过来又帮助国家适应变化。然而，新的均衡是不稳定的，尤其是经济和征兵问题，有可能引发进一步的动荡。

不羁的羊

从表面上看，大多数俄罗斯人都温顺地接受了乌克兰战争即将过去两年的事实。三分之二的人告诉民意调查专家俄罗斯菲尔德，该国正在朝着正确的方向前进，超过一半的人表示乌克兰战争进展顺利。 “我知道社会是完全墨守成规的，但我仍然没想到心理适应的程度如此令人难以置信。人们只是把自己封闭起来，试图过上平常的生活，”学者纳拉利亚·祖巴列维奇(Nalalya Zubarevich)在最近的一次采访中说道。

公开抗议很少见，原因显而易见。 11 月 16 日，艺术家兼活动家亚历山德拉·斯科奇连科 (Alexandra Skochilenko) 因用反战信息替换圣彼得堡一家超市的价格标签而被判入狱七年。 （“我的曾祖父没有在第二次世界大战2中战斗，以便俄罗斯可以成为法西斯的国家并攻击乌克兰。”一读。）不仅仅是迫害的不仅仅是Peaceniks：至少有一个超民族主义的持不同政见者伊戈尔·吉尔金（Igor Girkin），一个退休的士兵和博客作者因抱怨普京的战斗不够多。

但是，仅仅因为大多数俄罗斯人接受了战争并不意味着他们对此充满热情。一部匆忙的宣传电影，讲述了乌克兰的“法西斯主义者”的成本为200万美元，是一部壮观的失败，在票房只收取15万美元。尽管他们对战争有所支持，但即使普京本人呼吁俄罗斯田地民意测验的受访者，俄罗斯领域的民意测验也与进一步的动员相反。十月，战争期间，大多数受访者第一次表示支持对继续战斗的和平谈判（见图1）。完全有74％的人表示，普京立即签署和平协议会很高兴。

也许毫不奇怪的是，年轻人是，他们从社交媒体而不是国有电视中获取新闻，对战争的持怀疑态度越大。然而，更引人注目的是，越丰富，受过教育的人越多，他们的支持越多（请参见图2）。正如俄罗斯匿名学者在最近的在线出版物Meduza的一篇文章中解释的那样，有一大批官僚和商人通过赞助人获得了自己的地位，并且将维护该政权来保护它。学者写道：“他们数百万，已经适应军事侵略的道德经济。”

在某种程度上，像其他所有人一样，这些人会因恐惧而陷入困境。在战争的头几个月中，国有公司的商人和经理的一系列神秘的死亡有助于灌输忠诚。俄罗斯最大的私营石油公司Lukoil董事会主席，在董事会发表声明呼吁停火后几个月后，莫斯科的医院窗口倒下。西方对寡头的制裁也有助于使货币阶级加入。

把目光移开

但是，公务员和商人也有很长的经验来抑制顾虑和处理系统。许多人从苏联官僚机构顺利过渡。 “他们不是由意识形态驱动，而是忠于公司的忠诚，无论是中央银行还是财政部。”他们认为使国家浮动船的任务是一项专业挑战，而不是道德上的困境。

44岁的数字化转型部长Maksut Shadaev就是一个很好的例子。在1990年代，他在私人IT公司工作，然后加入政府，以帮助建立一个时尚，用户友好的网站和移动应用程序，使公民可以访问诸如医生任命和入学的公共服务。现在，他正在使用相同的技能来构建一个称为“数字古拉格”的系统，这是一个全面的注册，以帮助跟踪有资格获得草案的男性。

同样，俄罗斯的企业帮助稳定了对国家的任何感情的稳定，而是因为他们擅长应对自己情况的大型，出乎意料且经常任意的转变。哈佛大学的安德烈·雅科夫列夫（Andrei Yakovlev）对俄罗斯企业家进行了调查，他说，经历了几次金融危机并与掠夺性官僚进行了不断的战斗，他们为为最糟糕的情况做准备。同时，西方进口商品的消失和西方公司的关闭为俄罗斯公司开辟了新的利基市场。同时，中央银行实施的资本管制使他们几乎没有选择，但要投资俄罗斯。政府提供了贷款，甚至下令官僚们不要骚扰他们。

当然，它有助于大量的石油货币围绕经济倾斜。在战争的第一年，俄罗斯的出口收入为5900亿美元，其中最多是石油和天然气。根据RE：俄罗斯的计算，俄罗斯是专家网络，比过去十年的年平均水平高1600亿美元。在第二年，收入仍应比平均水平高600亿美元。回复：俄罗斯认为，这场战争每年至少要花100亿美元，因此，石油的额外收入涵盖了发动它的大部分费用。

去年，政府的预算增长了26％，明年将增加16％。明年的国防支出将几乎翻一番，占GDP的6％，这是自苏联崩溃以来最高的。现在，它占政府支出的三分之一。同时，在健康和教育方面的支出是真实的。正如财政部长安东·西鲁阿诺夫（Anton Siluanov）最近宣布的那样，“主要重点是确保我们的胜利。陆军，国防能力，武装部队，战士 - 战线所需的一切，胜利所需的一切都在预算中。”

这样的豪华支出不会无限期地可持续。中央银行正在努力限制通货膨胀率上升，今年第三季度的年增长率为12％。它已将利率提高到15％。同时，当局正在迫使出口商将其收入转换为卢布，以避免进一步贬值，这会加剧通货膨胀。根据俄罗斯领域的数据，约有43％的俄罗斯人预计他们的经济状况会恶化，而只有21％的俄罗斯人期望它会改善。

然而，目前，有一个富裕，尤其是在经济的某些地区和俄罗斯社会的某些部分。 “与石油不同，枪支驱动工业增长，”亚历山德拉·普罗科本科（Alexandra Prokopenko）和帕维尔·卢津（Pavel Luzin）在智囊团卡内基俄罗斯中心（Carnegie Russia Centr）中。在战区附近或许多弹药工厂的地区，建筑，消费和服务正在增长。在远东地区，基础设施有大量投资以扩大与亚洲的贸易，因为与欧洲的关系已枯萎。

莫斯科和圣彼得堡从新秩序中受益不多，而是沮丧的工业区域 - 普京的心脏地带 - 生活比多年来的生活要好。在伊兹夫斯克（Izhevsk），这是一个靠近乌拉尔山脉（Ural Mountains）的贫穷城市，该城市为电子战生产枪支，导弹和设备，自战争开始以来，平均工资增长了25％。一家有机的超市Vkusvill和一家泛亚洲餐厅皇家劳斯莱斯（Royal Lolls）最近开业。在唐·罗斯托夫（Rostov-on-Don），军事区的总部涵盖了前线，餐饮业的营业额增加了77％。 Zubarevich女士说：“许多食欲良好的男人到达那里。”

俄罗斯广阔而贫穷的腹地也从当局悬挂的现金中受益，以便为军队确保更多的新兵。那些志愿者的人每月约为195,000卢布，这是伊兹夫斯克新近平均工资的四倍，而入伍195,000卢布的一次性奖金则是一次性奖金。战斗中被杀的人的家人也得到了慷慨的付款。波兰华沙高级研究所的俄罗斯经济学家Vladislav Inozemtsev估计，在服役五个月后被杀害的士兵家族总共将获得约1500万卢布，包括薪酬和薪酬。平均需要30年的俄罗斯男子才能赚多少钱。 Inozemtsev先生认为，俄罗斯男子的预期寿命只有65。普京政权试图将被杀成为经济理性的选择。

尽管如此，俄罗斯似乎有人力问题。一年前的强迫动员宣布了第二次世界大战以来的第一次，引起了恐慌和愤怒。入伍委员会被放火，成千上万的年轻人逃离了该国或藏在俄罗斯境内。那些被召唤的人当时仍在前线，尽管承诺他们只能服务六个月。这产生了由他们的妻子和名叫Voina Zaebala的妻子和母亲（战争搞砸了）领导的抗议运动。 “我们不会生孩子被杀，”一位激动的母亲在社交媒体上广泛流传的视频中抱怨道。

警察不仅在精力上寻找草稿，而且还寻找来自中亚的移民，他们似乎正在挤压兵役。他们最近突袭了俄罗斯最大的在线零售商Wildberries属于Wildberries的仓库，并停止了服务。也经常对学生宿舍进行突袭。

同时，俄罗斯议会杜马正在准备更多的动员。受征兵的最大年龄已从27岁提高到30岁。前军人仍然保留的时间已延长了五年，就初级官员而言已有60年。法律已被更改，要求雇主上交兵役。正如杜马国防委员会主席安德烈·卡托波洛夫（Andrei Kartopolov）解释说：“这项法律是为一场大战而写的，是为了进行一般动员。而且您已经可以在空中闻到这么大的战争。”

但是缺乏人力并不是军队唯一的问题。 “俄罗斯军事改革与军国主义”的作者亚历山大·戈尔茨（Aleksandr Golts）认为，它也缺乏初级官员，培训能力和设备。较高的军事支出很可能是极低效率的。众所周知，俄罗斯的军备业是腐败的：估计有些回扣是采购成本的两倍。它也饿死了熟练的劳动。副总理尤里·波里索夫（Yuri Borisov）表示，它需要另外40万工程师， IT专家和经理。

有人谈到要增加国家对经济的控制，以缩小战争的努力。负责军事采购的副总理丹尼斯·曼杜罗夫（Denis Manturov）表示，国防行业可能必须重新引入国家规划。 “我们正在谈论战争条件下的经济安全……让我们走下经济主要部门的国有化之路，”反腐败局负责人，普京先生的大学同学亚历山大·巴斯特金（Alexander Bastrykin）说。十八家大公司已于2023年国有化，其中许多以恢复被掠夺的财产到该州的名义。检察官向普京报告说，法院已听取了24,000起涉及国家财产损失的案件。

国有公司在俄罗斯生活中发挥了越来越大，越来越多的一部分。例如，俄罗斯国有天然气垄断俄罗斯天然气工天然天然天然组织拥有几个媒体。它还载有，装备和资助了几个军事旅。国有石油巨头Rosneft建造了船只并监督有关人类基因组欧亚变种的研究项目。

监督这些庞大的帝国的官僚通常是商人，其利益重叠。例如，曼杜罗夫先生坐在国防部的国防企业集团Rostec董事会上。 Rostec的董事长是Sergei Chemezov，他是前克格勃特工，他曾在东德与普京一起服役。 Chemevoz先生和Manturov先生的家庭共同拥有港口，酒店，豪华物业和葡萄园等。

越来越普遍的模式是普京的朋友和同事的孩子在工业和政府中扮演重要角色。农业部长德米特里·帕特鲁瑟夫（Dmitry Patrushev）是国家安全委员会秘书尼古拉·帕特鲁瑟夫（Nikolai Patrushev）的儿子。普京先生的女儿埃卡特琳娜·蒂克霍诺瓦（Ekaterina Tikhonova）主席商业大厅集团的进口替代委员会。俄罗斯最大的社会媒体平台Vkontakte部分由多家国有公司拥有，并由普京先生的副局长的儿子以及由有钱商人的伟大侄子共同经营，据说是一位有钱的商人，据说是MR之一。普京最接近的知己和倡导乌克兰的倡导者。

俄罗斯在战争开始时禁止Facebook和Instagram的决定使Vkontakte的用户在短短几周内提高了400万。现在，它的渗透率为75％，被认为是由安全服务密切监视的，并且有助于传播亲战消息。 “这是普京的梦想，也是一个理想的典范：在克格勃（KGB）的监督下由孩子们经营的一切，” RE：俄罗斯的创始人Kirill Rogov说。

犯罪英雄

为了证明他对俄罗斯经济的重建合理性并解释了他缺乏军事成就的原因，普京先生将战争重新定义为不是与乌克兰的战争，而是与西方的战争，其中乌克兰只是用来欺骗俄罗斯的“殴打公羊”。新的历史教科书向学生解释说，俄罗斯曾经和将永远与西方处于战争状态。这种叙述使普京先生将日常活动描述为胜利。他在入侵周年纪念日的一场演讲中夸口说：“使俄罗斯公司能够成功地利用市场是一场胜利……建立尖端工厂和新道路是一场胜利……科学发现和新技术 - 这些也是胜利。” 。

这样的谈话暗示了普京对战争的核心的矛盾。他希望在战斗中动员更多的人力和金钱，同时通过尽可能少地破坏自己的生活来确保俄罗斯人的默许。随着俄罗斯在俄罗斯的重新分配，更多的权力和资源将变得更加明显。他的政权最令人震惊的时刻是在六月，当时陆军与瓦格纳之间的争吵，瓦格纳（Wagner）是一个由普京先生的密友耶夫根·普里戈什（Yevgeny Prigozhin）领导的雇佣军团体，升级为彻底的叛变。尽管Prigozhin先生迅速退缩，后来在一次方便的飞机失事中死亡，但提醒人们，在俄罗斯精英中平衡竞争利益并不容易。随着经济错位的增加和资源的越来越稀缺，这些冲突只会增加。 ■

从11月30日，来自世界各地的70,000人将在迪拜参加联合国年度气候峰会。众所周知，警察是一个为期12天的jamboree，吸引了外交官，商人和活动家。如果他们有时间逃避世博会的恋爱，并前往闪闪发光的摩天大楼，散落着海岸，他们将在惊人的繁荣中找到一个城市和一个国家。

一个赠品是众多俄罗斯亿万富翁，印度商人和西方金融家的人群。另一个是财产疯狂。 9月，买家在凌晨排队，在迪拜最新的Ritzy Land-Reclamation计划的Palm Jebel Ali中抢购别墅，起价为500万美元。这些属性尚未建立。

去年的能源价格尖峰带来了全球最大的石油生产商之一阿拉伯联合酋长国，收入超过100亿美元。每个阿联酋公民约有100,000美元。但是石油并不是该国繁荣的唯一原因。在战争和经济分散时期，阿联酋似乎是风暴中的港口。跨国公司正在以先前在阿联酋独立五十年中看不见的速度建立工厂和办公室。现在，石油和天然气仅占GDP的三分之一，而经济的油腻碎片的增长速度比其余部分慢。与2022年的同一时期相比，上半年的整个经济增长了3.7％。不包括石油和相关行业，增长了5.9％（请参阅图1）。

阿联酋在世界上的地位似乎也在迅速发展。托管COP 28是一个迹象。这个国家只有1000万人口，其中只有100万人是公民。但是，通过对全球商业和外国投资（包括清洁能源和物流）的拥抱，它对世界其他国家都有约束力。它的经济开放性及其对商业的非政治方法具有广泛的吸引力：这是美国，中国，伊朗，以色列人和俄罗斯人都擦肩而过的少数地方之一。

然而，阿联酋并非没有挑战。随着石油对经济的关键，社会契约正在发生变化。政府不仅仅是在石油公司中耙开，也不简单地以舒适的工作和补贴商品的形式将其分发给公民；它已经开始征收税收和促使当地人在私营部门寻求更多苛刻的工作。由于阿联酋是一个绝对的君主制（或者，其中七个结合在以最富有的阿布扎比​​为主导的联邦中），因此几乎没有流行的不满。缺乏对统治者权威的检查可能会导致任意和思考的决策，尤其是在外交关系中。

可以安装精神

这个国家对经济转型并不陌生。珍珠潜水是海湾沿岸的昏昏欲睡贸易哨所的先前的支柱，在20世纪初期，日本研究人员制定了如何耕种珍珠。石油在1950年代被发现；到1971年，当阿联酋从英国获得独立时，它就可以成为质石化。它的石油比俄罗斯高，并且是全球第七大生产商，每天要抽超过300万桶。相对于他们的人口，只有圭亚那和科威特有更多的石油。

尽管有这种赏金，但阿联酋的统治者还是海湾最早试图使经济多样化的统治者之一。迪拜（Dubai）自己几乎没有石油，它带领前进，创造了旨在吸引跨国公司的轻微监管，低税的经济区。尽管在2009年发生壮观的房地产崩溃后，阿布扎比（Abu Dhabi）的基本经济公式将自己转变为贸易企业，运输中心和金融中心仍然成功。同时，阿联酋已将其石油财富投资于战略上重要的行业和战略上重要的地区。目的是使自己成为全球贸易，金融和地缘政治的力量。当地人指出，这种方法中的许多方法都由邻国沙特阿拉伯王子穆罕默德·本·萨尔曼（Muhammad bin Salman）复制。

从阿联酋作为intrepot的角色开始。它在非洲，欧洲和亚洲大部分地区的易于飞行和运输距离之内，这一事实使其成为天然枢纽。 DP World是迪拜政府拥有的一家公司，经营着世界上最大的集装箱港口之一Jebel Ali。迪拜机场是世界上最繁忙的国际旅行。物流已经增长，占该国GDP的近8％。

但是商业氛围与地理一样重要。在美国智囊团遗产基金会（Heritage Foundation）编写的经济自由指数中，阿联酋在176个国家中排名第24位，在美国高于美国。外国人称赞可以设立办事处，租用公寓，签证批准的便利性。 “每个人都在商业上思考，没有人在政治上思考，”以色列企业家在迪拜的一个大职位上指出。在以色列和哈马斯之间的战争开始几周后，去该国旅行时，他发现阿联酋像以往一样热情。地方政府经营“客户幸福中心”。这个名字很畏惧，本地服务可能很昂贵，但它们起作用。

近年来，企业以疯狂的速度在迪拜成立：上半年加入该市商会的新企业的数量增长了40％以上，而2022年。 ;来自中国和中东其他地区的公司数量也迅速增长。同时，阿布扎比取得了一些成功的诱使金融公司。

涌入反映了阿联酋可以为来自不同国家的公司发挥的各种作用。对于中国人来说，它已成为一个离岸贸易中心。一个例子是Dragon Mart，这是迪拜的批发和零售综合体，它是中国以外的中国商品的最大交易中心。去年， DP World帮助建立了Yiwu市场，希望蚀它。对于印度公司而言，阿联酋为中国和东南亚提供了香港和新加坡所做的事情：在国际上开展业务的一个更容易的地方，具有更高效率的法院，更好的基础设施以及获得资本和人才的机会。它也已成为第二个家。印度最富有的人穆克什·安巴尼（Mukesh Ambani）在迪拜最昂贵的住宅物业的纪录是两倍，最近一次是1.63亿美元的海滩别墅。

对西方制裁的冷漠使阿联酋成为回避地方的企业的避风港。伊朗石油经常在富查伊拉（Fujairah）的酋长国（Emirate）与其他原油混合并出售。在日内瓦的商人开始避开俄罗斯原油之后，迪拜成为了资金和贸易货物的地方。俄罗斯商人不再能够居住在美国或欧洲，已搬到迪拜的海滨别墅。与此同时，香港在大流行期间似乎永无止境的封锁，派遣了一些专业人士逃往迪拜，那里的迪拜只持续了三个月。去年，从净的角度来看，去年的百万富翁搬到了阿联酋。

近年来，对外国企业的欢迎已经变得更加温暖，最可能是为了确保阿联酋在沙特阿拉伯中保持优势，而沙特阿拉伯现在也在追逐外国公司。局外人曾经需要与阿联酋合作，在该国开设商店，为当地人提供肥胖的租金并放缓的业务形成。 “代理”规则已经放松。周末已经从周五，周六到周六和周日转移，以与世界其他大部分地区保持一致（Sharjah的酋长国，热衷于确保星期五的假期，已经度过了四天的一周）。个人自由也增加了一点：例如，未婚夫妇现在可以一起生活。

但是一个小国只能吸引这么多的业务，这就是为什么阿联酋也冒险在国外冒险。它的各种主权卫生基金的资产在各种业务中的资产超过1.5trn（请参阅图2）。穆巴达拉（Mubadala）的各种持股包括美国金融科技公司（Chime），一家美国金融科技公司（Chime），Xpeng，一家中国电动车制造商Xpeng和Ambani先生的电信网络Jio等。

许多投资都在物流中。 DP World在伦敦到悉尼各地的港口。总而言之，不少于世界上的十分之一通过该公司的手中的运输。

还关注发展中国家。阿联酋是资本主义非洲最大的投资者之一，尽管主要是在北非。 “我们正在复制迪拜在非洲国家的成功。” DP世界老板苏丹·艾哈迈德·本·苏亚伊姆（Sultan Ahmed Bin Sulayem）在2020年说。2022年，包括阿布扎比港口在内的一个埃米尔拉蒂财团签署了一项协议，以在苏丹的港口和农业项目中投资60亿美元。 DP World也在干旱土地上运营：在卢旺达，它已经投资了一个公路运输中心，根据Knight Frank的一份报告，该中心将咨询公司的报告从几周到几天减少了国内运输时间。在印度，它已经投资了铁路线；在南部非洲，在一家物流公司。

另一个利基是清洁能源。 2006年，阿联酋制作了一个先见之明的赌注，成立了一家名为Masdar的公司，通过投资可再生能源来实现其能源供应并在其能源专业知识上建立多样化（该公司最初由苏丹·贾伯（Sultan al-Jaber）经营，后者现在负责阿布扎比的国家石油公司（Abu Dhabi）国家石油公司是Cop 28的总裁）。马斯达尔现在是世界上最大的风电场和太阳能开发商之一。

阿联酋官员希望在另一个新兴行业中实现类似的壮举：人工智能。阿布扎比很快努力抓住该技术的潜力，建立研究所，提供大量资本，并招募有才华的西方和中国研究人员。结果是猎鹰（Falcon），一种开源大语模型，一些技术人员认为，比梅塔（Meta）的产品（Llama 2.它希望出售。现在说Falcon是否会飞行还为时过早，但是与大多数关于其AI策略的政府不同，阿联酋似乎实际上有一个。

阿联酋还试图通过一系列双边经济和投资协议来促进其商业利益。这是亚伯拉罕协议的第一批签署国之一，在该协议下，几个阿拉伯国家与以色列建立了关系。随后是今年早些时候与以色列达成的贸易协议。即使在10月7日哈马斯发动袭击之后，西方航空公司暂停飞往特拉维夫的航班，两家阿联酋航空公司的弗莱杜比和阿提哈德也维持了定期的服务。

去年，印度与阿联酋签署了一项自由贸易协定，这是十年来的第一个。此后，双边贸易以名义增长了16％。与印度尼西亚达成了类似的协议。与泰国和马来西亚的会谈正在进行中。谈判的移动速度要比海湾合作委员会的同等努力快得多，海湾合作委员会的分组是所有富含石油的海湾国家的分组，使阿联酋可以偷走其邻国的游行。

但是，有时候，这似乎是外交必须决定商业决定的命令，而不是相反。阿联酋渴望在其地区建立影响力。本月初，它与约旦签署了一项协议，将共同投资200亿美元用于基础设施和开发项目。它凭借贸易和投资的承诺使土耳其总统雷德普·泰耶普·埃尔多安（Recep Tayyip Erdogan）合并。它还为埃塞俄比亚四面楚歌的总理阿比·艾哈迈德（Abiy Ahmed）提供了积极的支持，包括发起涉及DP World和Masdar的大型项目。

的确，在外交政策中，阿联酋总统和阿布扎比统治者穆罕默德·本·扎耶德（Muhammad bin Zayed）的绝对甚至是不可预测的权力。谢赫·穆罕默德（Sheikh Muhammad）对伊斯兰教的政治表达有害，并热衷于重塑该地区以增加阿联酋的影响力。在这一目的的情况下，他干预了利比亚，苏丹和也门的内战。

然而，在所有三个地方，战争不确定。此外，阿联酋在这三个地方都发现自己与美国或沙特阿拉伯等亲密盟友矛盾。更糟糕的是，尽管在每个国家，阿联酋已经支持似乎不太倾向于合并清真寺和国家的一方，但其盟友在其他方面是不愉快的。例如，在苏丹，阿联酋支持的民兵被指控在达尔富尔地区针对黑人非洲人进行了种族灭绝运动。

阿联酋的无人值得尊敬的盟友经常提高其商业利益，这无济于事。在苏丹，他们部分通过控制黄金矿的控制，其产量在迪拜大部分出售。阿联酋自然也渴望保护阿布扎比在苏丹的大投资。但是，充其量是短视的：很难想象，阿联酋从这种外国政策冒险中获得的任何商业利益都可能超过对其声誉的潜在损害。

不仅在外交政策中，阿联酋有时会因其统治者的判断力判断而失望。它已经成为了先见之明的经济赌注，但也鲁ck。从迪拜开车到阿布扎比，您经过一片荒凉的土地，曾经是为了容纳从未建造的主题公园。 2018年，联邦政府承诺在2021年对区块链进行一半的交易；迪拜的官员曾经承诺“到2020年将由区块链完全支持”。同样，商业环境并不完美。该政权可能是任意和苛刻的，例如，外国商人有时在没有解释的情况下被拘留。

到目前为止，此类失误还不够大，无法在阿联酋的公民或投资者中播种，因此破坏了其作为政治和经济稳定天堂的声誉。但是，随着其经济的增长越来越多，阿联酋的外国纠缠变得越来越复杂，管理所有竞争利益成为一项更加微妙的任务。同时，警察提醒我们阿联酋看似不可思议的财富实际上可能是浪费资产。

石油资金使阿联酋有可能在不暴露任何痛苦的情况下向世界开放其经济。阿布扎比是世界上成本最低的生产商之一，即使在消费量下降的世界中，也将继续从事石油业务。但是它正在准备一段时间，大富翁可能会减少。在某种程度上，这意味着使阿联酋对外国劳工和商业更具吸引力。但这也意味着寻找替代的收入来源和削减成本。政府已经提出了增值税和公司所得税。燃料补贴在2015年被淘汰。没有人大声说出来，但个人所得税似乎也不可避免。

更多的酋长国需要从公共部门转移到私营部门，但许多人没有资格，这意味着它们不太可能变得更加富有。学童在标准化测试中远远落后于他们富裕的同行，而辍学率很高。到目前为止，社会契约的未签署导致抱怨，但没有动荡。为了保持这种方式，将需要更加协调一致的努力来训练劳动力和微妙的感觉。

阿联酋已经很快发现了一个破碎的世界中的机会。然而，新时代也带来了危险。从化石燃料实现的话，全球过渡将是令人震惊的。阿联酋自信的外交政策将继续限制其联盟。特别是，它与沙特阿拉伯的关系可能变得更加复杂，更具竞争力。过去的50年表明，押注阿联酋是愚蠢的，但最艰难的测试仍然存在。 ■

; Thu, 23 Nov 2023 10:52:27 GMT /content/f3nl20jrtr1s646avd0bceevg8igder5 https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/11/11/23/the-messier-the-world-gets-the-more-the-more-the-uae-seem-seems-to-thive Now AI can write, sing and act, is it still possible to be a star?

N oisy crowds of beautiful people gathered outside Hollywood's film studios every weekday for the past six months, shouting slogans and marching in the sun. America's screenwriters and actors were striking, in part over fears that artificial intelligence ( AI ) will soon be writing scripts or even bagging roles. “You go for a job and they scan you,” said a background actress, who worried that her face will be used over and over in crowd scenes. The technology is “disgusting”, said another, who considered its use “an infringement of yourself, of your career”. The deal actors struck on November 8th to end their strike included protections from their artificial rivals.

Five thousand miles away another animated crowd can regularly be found chattering about AI , usually in gloomier weather but brighter spirits. Outside a purpose-built stadium in east London, giddy groups of all ages, some in fancy dress, gather seven times a week to watch ABBA Voyage, a performance in which a septuagenarian pop group plays an energetic 90-minute set via virtual avatars, generated with the help of AI . The show, launched in 2022, played to 1m people in its first year and still almost sells out on most nights, bringing in a reported $2ma week while ABBA ’s four members put their feet up.

Will AI leave talent impoverished, as Hollywood's protesting actors and writers fear, or further enrich them, as ABBA has found? It is easy to see why stars are nervous. Over the years technology has automated away many routine jobs in entertainment, but the creative work at the heart of the business has been protected.不再。 Generative AI is hoovering up copyrighted work and churning out remixed literature, music and video of all varieties, increasingly competing with humans in quality and already far outpacing them in quantity. In a world of infinite AI -generated content, is it even possible to be a star?

The talent are mobilising unions, lawyers and politicians to protect themselves. Hollywood's screenwriters, who ended their five-month strike in September, won a promise from studios to employ a minimum number of human writers on films and TV shows. The studios have retained the right to use AI to generate or polish scripts, but the AI will not be recognised as an author, so human writers' royalties will not be diluted. Writers, for their part, have kept the right to use AI in their own work. (Although they dislike it, many consider AI “the best writing partner they've ever had”, concedes a Hollywood agent.)

The details of the actors' deal with studios and streaming services had not been released as The Economist went to press, but the Screen Actors Guild, their union, said that it included “unprecedented provisions for consent and compensation that will protect members from the threat of AI ”. This is likely to mean that actors will at least be notified and paid if their likeness or voice is to be digitally reanimated.

I sue, I sue, I sue, I sue, I sue

The stars' second line of defence is legal. A group of authors including John Grisham (of “The Firm” and dozens more thrillers) and George RR Martin (of “Game of Thrones”) have filed a class-action lawsuit against Open AI , the Microsoft-backed company behind Chat GPT , arguing that it ingested their work without permission or payment. Another complaint by parties including Universal Music Group, the world's biggest record company, accuses Anthropic, an Amazon- and Google-backed AI firm, of doing something similar with song lyrics.

The tech firms argue that “training” an AI model on copyrighted work amounts to fair use. In the words of Matthew Sag of Emory University, AI does not copy a book “like a scribe in a monastery” so much as learn from it like a student. Pieces of training data, whether novels or songs, usually play such a small role in the model's output as to be barely traceable.但不总是。 “If you say, 'Write in the style of Dan Brown [of “The Da Vinci Code”],' of course it will pull from Dan Brown's books,” declares Mary Rasenberger, head of the Authors Guild, which represents writers.

As the courts grind into action, governments are also getting involved. On October 30th Joe Biden, America's president, issued an executive order setting out basic rules for AI development. The US Copyright Office is running an inquiry into AI , which will close to comments later this month.

There is a risk that governments will compete to create the most “permissive” regulatory environment, to attract AI firms, warns a music-industry insider. Others, citing past waves of tech-driven disruption, see room for compromise. When music-streaming arrived, “We got very defensive, and only defensive,” admits another senior record-company executive. It took a decade for the labels to realise that the technology was good for business, and do a deal with the streaming platforms. Negotiations with AI companies will take less than half that time, he predicts. “It's co-existence that's required.”

When the law is settled, who will win and lose from the technology? On the face of it, the biggest stars seem most vulnerable. AI helps ordinary people narrow the gap with the most gifted. Less glamorous industries have already witnessed this. In April a working paper by Erik Brynjolfsson of Stanford University and others found that novice customer-support agents were 35% more productive when given access to a chatbot, whereas experienced agents hardly benefited.

Something similar is happening in show business. Even before AI , tools like autotune were helping ordinary mortals to sound more like their idols. The next generation of technology promises to make such features more powerful. TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, is trialling an app called Ripple which takes any melody that users sing into their phone and turns it into a polished song. Boomy, an American startup, lets amateur composers generate original tunes with a few clicks and upload them to earn royalties on streaming platforms such as Spotify.

Frumpy actors can vie with gorgeous ones thanks to the digital facelifts of tools such as Vanity AI , which are used in productions like “Stranger Things” and “The Walking Dead” to make actors look prettier or scarier, as required. Dull writers can get inspiration from apps such as Sudowrite, which suggests new ideas and edits. It bills itself pithily as “the non-judgmental, always-there-to-read-one-more-draft, never-runs-out-of-ideas-even-at-3am AI writing partner you always wanted”.

Not much AI -made work is good, let alone dazzling enough to compete with the stars at the top of the talent tree. But it is starting to have an impact through sheer scale. Boomy claims to have generated nearly 18m songs (for comparison, Spotify's entire catalogue is a little over 100m). Spotify now adds more than 100,000 new tracks every day, many of them AI -made. Sir Lucian Grainge, the head of Universal Music, has warned that real music could drown in a “sea of noise” as streaming platforms fill up with amateur tracks. Professional artists' share of listening is indeed sinking. In 2017 artists signed to record labels accounted for 87% of the streams on Spotify. Last year their share was only 75%.

AI struggles to make real hits, but is good at churning out the kind of music that people have on in the background while working or going to sleep.这些曲目的播放时间很长，因此在流媒体使用的付费模式下可以获得丰厚的回报。一些业内人士怀疑，流媒体平台欢迎业余艺术家的崛起，而业余艺术家的议价能力不如大唱片公司。另一位唱片公司高管表示，流媒体可能会促使听众关注这些内容的想法“绝对令人担忧”。他认为唯一阻止他们的是惹恼听众的风险。主播们反驳说，宣传不良音乐根本不符合他们的利益。 Earlier this year Spotify purged lots of AI -made songs and is said to be rejigging its rules to make low-quality wallpaper music less profitable; Deezer 和 Tidal 这两个规模较小的竞争对手也采取了类似的措施。

The publishing world has similar complaints. Producing entire books by AI is so quick and easy that, in September, Amazon banned authors from self-publishing more than three e-books a day on its Kindle platform and required publishers to clearly label books by robot writers. Most AI texts are full of cliché and waffle (which makes them competitive in the management genre, an agent quips). But some are taking sales away from human authors by deception: the Authors Guild has spotted a tendency for AI -made biographies to land just before real memoirs are published, for instance. “Click farms” have also been deployed to manipulate Amazon's rankings. The guild says that, at one point this summer, 40 of the top 100 young-adult romance books on Kindle were AI -written.

The winner makes it all

Yet far from sinking in this sea of AI -made entertainment, the biggest stars of all seem to be more buoyant than ever. As record labels worry about robot composers, Taylor Swift is halfway through what will probably be the highest-earning concert tour in history, with projected sales of $1.4bn or more (no previous tour has breached $1bn). An accompanying film has made an additional $230m at the box office. Colleen Hoover, a writer of romantic young-adult fiction, crushed the robot writers last year to bag eight places on the top-25 bestseller list in America, selling 14m copies, according to Publishers Weekly , a trade title.

One of the paradoxes of the internet age is that, amid an explosion in online content on platforms from YouTube to TikTok, fans have flocked as never before to the biggest acts. It has been a good time to be an amateur creator, but an even better time to be a superstar. Data from Spotify show that between 2017 and 2022, as the platform was flooded with tens of millions of amateur tracks, the number of artists making at least $1,000 a year in royalties increased by 155%. At the same time, the number making $5m or more increased by 165%, and the handful of headliners making $10m or more increased by 425% (see chart 1 on previous page). Those who have done least well are middling-to-big artists, who face more competition from entertainment's long tail but have been unable to break into the elite group at the top.

Similar patterns can be seen across the entertainment world. Better and cheaper technology has democratised filmmaking. The number of movies released each year in America more than doubled during the first two decades of the 21st century, but the audience-share of the biggest blockbusters has grown, not shrunk. In 2019 (the last year before the pandemic) America's five biggest films took a quarter of the domestic box office, nearly double the share they took in the less crowded market of 2000 (see chart 2). Meanwhile, the ten bestselling authors have accounted for a steady 2-3% of book sales in Britain over the past decade, according to Nielsen, a data company, even though 2m more books are self-published each year.

Lay all your likes on me

“Hits will persist in an infinite-content world,” argues Doug Shapiro, a former media executive. The bewildering variety makes it hard for consumers to pick, so they rely more on recommendations, whether from friends or algorithms. Rather than browse, people seek out what they have already heard of, says Ms Rasenberger of the Authors Guild. “Known writers are selling. And everyone else is having a much harder time.”

AI also helps superstars shine brighter by creating opportunities for their admirers to become superfans. Followers of a music act used to express themselves chiefly through “records, T -shirts and mix-tapes”, says an industry executive. Now the internet offers “mix-tapes on steroids”. Fans can duet with their idols or dance to their music on social media. Games like “Fortnite” have provided a venue for interactive experiences: Ariana Grande held a concert-game hybrid on the platform in 2021, attracting 27m participants.

AI -powered technology promises to allow the biggest stars to be in even more places, gratifying even more fans. The producers of ABBA Voyage are in talks to bring the show to cities in North America, South-East Asia and Australasia, according to Per Sundin, head of Pophouse, a Swedish entertainment company that is the biggest investor in the enterprise. Other artists have been in touch, looking to “cement and elevate their legacies” with similar shows, he says. “We now have a proven template.”

Stars do not need to build their own arena like ABBA to use ai to be in more places at once. Spotify is working with Open AI to translate podcasts into different languages, allowing broadcasters to be heard in more markets, in their own voice. Other firms such as HeyGen provide dubbing services for video, using AI to change the movement of the actor's lips to match what they are saying. HeyGen recently created a viral video of Ms Swift appearing to speak fluent Chinese. Such platforms can adapt content in other ways, too, for instance by toning down strong language for a broader audience. Technology like this will allow stars to reach more viewers—and presents a problem to the lowlier actors who specialise in dubbing.

Stars are also using ai to travel in time. John Lennon re-entered the charts on November 2nd with “Now and Then”, old recordings of his voice having been salvaged using AI . (“I hope someone does this to all my crap demos after I'm dead—make them into hit songs,” said his late fellow Beatle, George Harrison, of an earlier attempt to resurrect Lennon's work.) James Earl Jones, who is 92 and first voiced Darth Vader almost 50 years ago, has sold Disney the right to replicate his gravelly tones artificially. A virtual Darth appeared in Disney's “Obi-Wan Kenobi” last year.

Some artists are experimenting with licensing their voice or image more widely. In April Grimes, a Canadian singer, invited amateur composers to clone her voice for use in their songs, provided they share any royalties with her. In September Meta launched 28 chatbot characters, played by celebrities. Snoop Dogg, Paris Hilton and Charlie D'Amelio are among the B -listers to be botified, with one reportedly being paid $5m over two years. Mark Zuckerberg, Meta's boss, invites stars to “build an AI version of yourself…to help people fulfil this desire to interact with you and your desire to build a community.”

A -listers remain wary: “Their voice is their career,” says a record executive. But even if they do not license their voice or likeness, others may still borrow them. A company called Socialdraft sells $5 “prompts” to make chatbots take on the personality of celebrities ranging from Tom Cruise to Josef Stalin, who do not appear to have given their permission. It is named in a legal complaint by a group of authors including Mr Grisham, whom it also impersonates. (Socialdraft denies wrongdoing. Antonio Evans, its chief executive, says, “The interplay between AI , copyright and individual rights is a thrilling narrative we are all part of.”)

Some unauthorised clones have become hits. In April an anonymous amateur composer released a song called “Heart On My Sleeve”, using the AI -replicated voices of two rappers, Drake and The Weeknd. The song was streamed 20m times before Universal, which represents the two artists, demanded it be taken down.

The track caused alarm, but it also demonstrated how cloning can work in artists' favour. Analysis by Will Page, author of “Pivot” and a former chief economist at Spotify, suggests that being cloned can help stars sell genuine music. He calculates that after David Guetta, a French DJ , posted a clip of an AI -generated rap in the style of Eminem in February, streams of real Eminem tracks rose by about a fifth.

Yet antipathy to AI remains fierce. A group of actors, writers and directors has set up an outfit called Credo23 to certify films and TV shows made without AI (it has yet to take off). Many singers, burned by digital piracy in the past, are also hostile. Sir Cliff Richard, an 83-year-old crooner, recently declared that his singing “didn't use artificial insemination”.

Others fear that AI will simply make entertainment derivative and boring. Three-quarters of Americans tell YouGov, a pollster, that they worry AI will sap human creativity. The process of ingesting everything and then spitting out an average may lead to a stylistic and conceptual regression to the mean, says a literary agent, who sees similarities with the algorithms on social media that help propagate the most pedestrian views. Sir Lucian, at Universal, has said that AI “will always lack the essential spark that drives the most talented artists to do their best work, which is intention”.

Everything depends on whether audiences embrace artificial performances. “Is the next generation of moviegoers going to want to see a different actor in James Bond, as an example? Or are they going to want to see Sean Connery come back?” asks a Hollywood agent. AI -generated performances may prove to be most successful for the biggest stars, whose uncritical superfans cannot get enough of them. As Liam Gallagher, a former Oasis frontman and John Lennon devotee, replied when asked on social media what he thought of the remastered “Now and Then”: “The Beatles could shit in my hand bag I'd still hide my polo mints in there ”。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 09:56:28 GMT /content/eoqrkuic0pt1gnnakeumo1cgj5dodaid https://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/11/09/now-ai-can-write-sing-and-act-is-it-still-possible-to-be-a-star人工智能 Markets think interest rates could stay high for a decade or more

N OT LONG ago, as interest rates in the rich world hovered near zero, economists debated whether their downward march was the product of a decades-, centuries- or millennia-long trend. Now the burning question is how long they will stay high. On October 18th the ten-year Treasury yield, which incorporates long-term expectations for interest rates and was below 1% as recently as 2021, hit 4.9%, its highest since 2007. The 30-year Treasury yield crossed 5% the same day 。 Analysts at Bank of America may have sounded a little breathless when they declared last month that rates were “coming off 5,000-year lows”. But that is indeed how it feels to economists, investors and anyone in the uncomfortable position of servicing debts they incurred when almost everyone expected rates to be low for ever.

The conviction that rates will remain “higher for longer” is spreading around the world. The euro zone saw negative interest rates in 2021; now Germany must pay nearly 3% to borrow for a decade. Britain's bond yields are nearly as high as America's. Even Japan, whose apparently permanently low rates were seen as a harbinger for the rest of the world, has faced upward pressure on its bond yields (see chart 1). Bets that its central bank will have to raise interest rates in 2024 for the first time since 2007 are mounting.

If markets are right, a new era is beginning and the consequences will be far reaching. Households and companies will have to pay much more to borrow. The financial system will have to adjust to a painful new reality. And governments will find they have to divert more tax revenue to pay the interest on their accumulated debt. The higher-for-longer scenario that many investors are now predicting is a potentially toxic mix.

Start with the real economy. One of the surprises of the past year is how resilient the world economy—and particularly America—has been in the face of higher rates. On October 26th it was revealed that America's GDP grew at an annualised pace of 4.9% in the third quarter. Consumer spending has been supported by the excess savings households built up thanks to the lockdowns and stimulus payments of the covid-19 pandemic. Many firms issued long-term debt when rates were low, and so continue to enjoy low financing costs today. Net interest payments by America's companies have actually fallen this year, because the interest they earn on the cash they keep to hand has risen faster than the cost of servicing their debts.

These protective buffers will last for a while yet. In September statisticians revised up the estimate of savings accumulated during the pandemic, which had previously looked like they were on the verge of exhaustion. It now appears that America's households are still sitting on about $1trn of excess cash, equal to nearly 5% of annual personal income in aggregate. It will also take time for higher rates to slow companies down. Goldman Sachs, a bank, estimates that just 16% of America's corporate debt will mature over the next few years. Refinancing it will lift the average interest rate on the total stock of debt from 4.2% this year to just 4.5% in 2025.

Not all companies are resilient to higher rates, however. Smaller American firms, whose debts typically fall due sooner than those of big ones, are under strain even though the economy is booming. There and in Europe, where growth is weaker, corporate bankruptcies are rising (see chart 2). In some economies firms are much more exposed to rising rates: at the end of 2021 the median maturity of Spanish and Italian businesses' debts was only 2.6 years and 2.1 years respectively. In Sweden, where corporate debt is an eye-watering 155% of GDP , the average effective interest rate on outstanding bank loans to companies rose from 1.5% to 3.9% in the year to March and will be higher still by now. In September the number of corporate bankruptcies was 14% higher than a year earlier.

Were rates to reach a permanently higher plateau, even long-dated debt would eventually start to cost companies dear. That would be painful because during the 2010s firms borrowed heavily: America's non-financial corporations issued a net $4.1trn in debt over that decade while retiring a net $3.2trn of equity through dividends and buy-backs. In advanced economies as a whole, corporate debt is around 93% of GDP , up from less than 80% in the mid-2000s, according to data from the IMF . If rates stay higher for longer, this borrowing binge may need to be unwound. A long period of deleveraging could therefore inhibit investment in the 2020s, just as low growth inhibited it in the 2010s.

Home is where the hurt is

Households, too, will eventually find that higher rates bite. In America and some European countries interest rates on mortgages can be fixed for decades, which protects borrowers from rate rises as long as they do not move house. But house prices are likely to fall, because they depend mostly on buyers who borrow afresh, and therefore face much higher costs. On October 18th Mortgage News Daily, a data provider, reported that the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in America carried an interest rate of 8% for the first time since 2000. As a result the monthly payment required to buy the median American home with a mortgage worth 90% of the property's value is now nearly 60% of average earnings, up from 33% in July 2021.

It strains credulity to think that housing markets can sustain such ratios. According to the Bank for International Settlements, real house prices in 12 advanced economies fell by 10% between the start of 2022 and the second quarter of 2023. Should rates follow the path implied by markets, real house prices should fall by another 14% by the end of 2025. In a scenario in which interest rates stabilise slightly above their current level, the peak-to-trough fall in real house prices would reach 35%. For comparison, the fall prompted by the global financial crisis was 13%.

Next, consider the implication of higher rates for the financial sector. Traders often joke that interest rates go up until something breaks. In the spring of 2023 something did: banks. They own lots of government bonds, which lose value as rates rise. The jump in the yield of ten-year Treasuries from 1.5% at the end of 2021 to around 3.5% a year later drove down the value of a broad index of Treasury bonds by about 10%. That inflicted over $600bn of losses on American banks, the most vulnerable of which—Silicon Valley Bank and First Republic—suffered runs and failed. The crisis was eventually forestalled by the Federal Reserve offering to lend to banks against the face value, rather than the market value, of their Treasuries, easing the pressure on their balance sheets.

But in a higher-for-longer world, the crisis could return. The last loans under the Fed's new lending scheme are to be made in March. Even if it is extended, banks may find themselves unable to afford to pay the interest on the Fed loans (which is similar to prevailing short-term rates and so has been rising steadily).

And it is not just Treasuries whose market value falls when rates rise. More or less any loan paying a fixed return over a medium-to-long duration will follow the same pattern. Erica Jiang, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski and Amit Seru, a group of economists, undertook an analysis that valued all the assets of American banks at the market prices that prevailed in March and then tested to see what would happen if half or all of their uninsured depositors withdrew their savings. They found that, even under the less apocalyptic scenario, some 200 or so banks, with collective assets of $300bn, would potentially be insolvent. Another paper, by Mark Flannery and Sorin Sorescu, two more economists, concluded, “If all unbooked losses were fully reflected in bank balance sheets, roughly half of all banks, holding roughly half of all bank assets, would not meet their minimum regulatory capital要求。”

Since March the bond index has fallen by 5% more. Ms Jiang and her co-authors have repeated their analysis. They find that unrealised losses have climbed modestly, but are now concentrated at bigger banks. In March only some 30% of the $2.2trn of these losses were at banks labelled “systemically important” by regulators. Now there are $2.5trn of unrealised losses, with about two-thirds at such banks.

There are other sources of financial vulnerability, too. Commercial property loans make up around a tenth of bank assets, and the value of office buildings has collapsed owing to higher interest rates and lower occupancy. Some owners have simply handed the keys to lenders. What is more, much lending has migrated in recent years from banks to other sorts of financial institutions, such as pension funds and insurance firms. They have never gone through a cycle of rising rates as big lenders before. Although the dispersal of risk is in principle helpful, it also means a greater number of firms face potential losses.

Last, consider the vulnerability of governments. After the global financial crisis, rich countries' public debts surged to the highest level since 1946. Since the pandemic they have been larger, relative to GDP , than at any time since the Napoleonic wars (see chart 3). The sustainability of these massive debts depends not just on interest rates, but on how those rates compare with economic growth. In the low-rate era it became fashionable to note that if GDP expands faster than interest accrues, then a government's debt-to- GDP ratio can shrink even as it borrows afresh to pay its interest bill. It may even be able to borrow more still to fund extra spending while keeping its debt-to- GDP ratio stable.

In October the IMF projected that, between 2023 and 2028, the economic growth rate in advanced economies will continue to exceed the interest rate their governments pay on their debts, by 1.4 percentage points on average, despite recent rate rises. The reason is that governments, like companies, have locked in low rates to some degree by issuing long-term debt.

Yet debt-to- GDP ratios are mostly set to rise anyway, because many governments continue to run excessive deficits. America especially is borrowing with abandon: strip out accounting distortions and its deficit for the past year was 7.5% of GDP , according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a think-tank. Deficits that high are typically seen only during wars or catastrophic recessions. The Economist calculated the fiscal adjustments that advanced economies would need to make to keep their debts stable, given the IMF ’s projections. In every big advanced economy bar Germany and Japan, belt-tightening is needed to stop the debt-to- GDP ratio from rising further. America would have to trim its primary budget deficit—ie, its deficit excluding interest on its debt—by an annual 2.4% of GDP . Such parsimony will be especially difficult given the extra spending that is needed to cope with ageing populations, the climate crisis and rising geopolitical tensions—the annual bill for all of which, the IMF estimates, will add up to about 7.5% of gdp in rich国家。

What is more, in a higher-for-longer world governments, like companies, must refinance eventually. Ten-year yields are now above plausible estimates of long-run growth in most rich economies. That means much more belt-tightening could be needed to keep debts from rising. It is hard to escape the conclusion that, on current growth forecasts, higher-for-longer would force governments into another round of painful budget-balancing like that suffered by Europe in the 2010s. If upheaval in the finance industry prompts expensive bail-outs, the fiscal outlook would become yet bleaker.

There is always cope

Can the world economy cope with corporate deleveraging, falling house prices, turmoil at banks and fiscal frugality? Surprisingly, the answer is, perhaps—if rates have risen for the right reason. Economists typically think that interest rates are determined in the long term by the balance between the world's desire to save and to invest. All else equal, more saving pulls down the so-called “natural” rate of interest; more investment pushes it up. The most popular explanation for the rock-bottom rates of the 2010s was that ageing populations were stashing away more money for retirement, while insipid long-term growth prospects had sapped companies of the desire to expand—a phenomenon sometimes called “secular stagnation”.

For rates to have shifted permanently, that outlook must have changed. One possible reason it might have is the anticipation of faster economic growth, driven, perhaps, by recent advances in artificial intelligence ( ai ). In the long term, growth and interest rates are intimately linked. When people's incomes rise over time, they have less need to save. Companies, expecting higher sales, become keener to invest. Central banks have to keep rates higher to stop economies from overheating.

It might seem farfetched to say that optimism about AI is pushing up bond yields. Yet it would explain why the prospect of higher-for-longer has not caused stockmarkets to fall much. In theory, higher bond yields should reduce the value of companies' future earnings, an effect that bites hardest for technology firms, since they tend to promise jam tomorrow. In fact, as optimism about AI has spread, the value of big tech firms such as Microsoft and Nvidia has soared. Their rising value has kept the cyclically adjusted price-earnings ratio of the S & P 500 at around pre-pandemic levels, even though bond yields—and hence the rate used to discount future profits—are now much higher. And America's strong growth in the third quarter was not driven by an unusual jobs boom; in fact, the labour market is cooling. If the growth number is accurate, productivity must have risen.

To the extent that productivity growth explains higher rates, the new era could be a happy one. Alongside the rise in debt-service costs, households will have higher real incomes, firms will have higher revenues, financial institutions will enjoy low default rates and governments will collect more tax. Healthy competition for capital might even bring benefits of its own. Some economists long suspected that the low-rate era of the 2010s made the economy less dynamic. “It was easy for relatively inefficient companies to stay afloat, so there wasn't much creative destruction,” says Kristin Forbes of MIT . In a higher-rate world underpinned by faster growth, there would be plenty of dynamism.

Alas, there is a more worrying explanation for higher rates: that government debt has grown so large that it has sopped up the world's surplus savings, leaving the private sector to compete for the scraps. In the short term, many traders blame the avalanche of debt issuance since the pandemic, as well as the unwinding of big bond purchases at central banks, for rising bond yields. Economists often pooh-pooh the significance of existing bonds changing hands, but they do think the size of the outstanding stock of debt matters. A rule of thumb proposed in 2019 by Larry Summers of Harvard University and Lukasz Rachel, then at the Bank of England, is that a ten-percentage-point increase in debt-to- GDP raises interest rates by 0.35 percentage points in the long run, while every percentage point increase in deficits raises rates by a similar amount. Other than a fiscal crisis, how could the tension be resolved? One possibility is that persistently high inflation could erode the real value of government debts, as it has in the past after moments of economic crisis. In that case, though nominal interest rates might be higher-for-longer, the real interest rate would not have risen as much. Companies and governments would survive high rates because their incomes would be strong in cash terms. Relative to the high real yields they expect today, bondholders would be squeezed.

Nearly three weeks after the October 7th massacre in Israel, however, that offensive has yet to begin. Israel's bombardment of Gaza continues, killing thousands and destroying around 9% of buildings in the territory . A near-total siege has left civilians short of food and water and hospitals unable to function.

Apart from a few small raids, though, the ground troops have yet to move. Some of the 360,000 reservists called up in Israel's largest-ever mobilisation have been sent home. Tens of thousands more are still in southern Israel, awaiting orders that have been delayed and delayed again.

Officers grumble that they cannot maintain their readiness forever. One frustrated commander took his troops to a building site to run up and down half-finished high-rises—ostensibly an urban-warfare drill. In reality, he says, it was a way to let off steam. “Hurry up and wait” is a perennial maxim of military life; but an especially stark one in Israel today.

There are many reasons to delay: continuing talks to free the array of hostages held by Hamas, the militant Islamist group that runs Gaza; American pressure, motivated by fears of a regional war; the dire conditions inside Gaza; and the chronic dithering of Binyamin Netanyahu, Israel's long-serving prime minister. On October 25th he confirmed that a ground offensive is still planned. But it will be smaller and slower than anyone would have expected in the days after the massacre, in which Hamas militants murdered more than 1,400 people, most of them civilians.

According to the latest count from Israeli officials, the tally of at least 220 people seized during the attack includes scores of children and old people, and citizens of at least a dozen foreign countries. The hostages have become a source of pressure on Mr Netanyahu's government. The captives' families have waged an effective public-relations campaign, and foreign leaders have pushed him to try to free their citizens.

Vigils have been held across Israel. The hostages' relatives often give television and radio interviews. The issue is deeply political. Many of those from the kibbutzim that were attacked are the secular, left-leaning sorts of Israelis most likely to have joined protests against Mr Netanyahu's government throughout the year. They feel his government forsook them on October 7th and is still failing them. Pressure from the families has already forced the government to change its plans. Originally inclined to rush into Gaza without regard for the hostages' safety, it has since declared that their rescue is a “top priority”.

Qatar, host to some leaders of Hamas, is also feeling the heat. Its ties with the group have come under scrutiny since the massacre; it is desperate to show its Western partners, particularly America, that it can serve as an interlocutor.

That Mr Hanegbi praised it (in English, rather than Hebrew) suggests progress towards a deal to release at least some of Hamas's captives.

Three days later it freed two elderly Israeli women who were abducted from Nir Oz, a kibbutz on the Gaza border. It got nothing in return—a sign that American pressure on Qatar is having an effect.

That the group behaved humanely to a grandmother, moreover, does not mitigate the outrage of having kidnapped a grandmother in the first place, tossing her across a motorbike and beating her with sticks. Nor does it excuse the horrors of what Hamas did in Israeli towns.

On October 23rd the Israeli army screened 43 minutes of raw footage from the massacre for foreign journalists. Some was taken from the attackers' body cameras, the rest from surveillance cameras and mobile phones. His fear that Israel is rushing into a war with no clear endgame is a valid one. The Israeli security establishment would like to see the PA , which governs parts of the occupied West Bank, also retake control in Gaza. But one senior official admits that no serious planning has been done. Mr Netanyahu even denied that such a plan exists.

Mr Biden also fears that the war will not stay in Gaza. On Israel's northern border with Lebanon, there have been daily exchanges of fire. Hizbullah, the Shia militia cum political party, has attacked Israeli towns and army posts with anti-tank missiles, and Israel has shelled and bombed southern Lebanon. Hizbullah admits that some 40 of its fighters have been killed (the real toll is probably higher). It is the most sustained fighting since the war they fought in 2006, though it has yet to escalate beyond tit-for-tat bombardment.

Militias in Syria and Iraq have used drones to attack American bases, where two dozen soldiers were lightly injured. On October 19th the Pentagon said an American destroyer, the USS Carney, had shot down missiles and drones launched from Yemen over the Red Sea. America believes their target was southern Israel, a remarkable entry into the war by the Houthis, an Iranian-backed militia in Yemen.

Dangerous calibrations

All of these escalations are small—signs that Iran wants to show the reach of its proxies, not plunge the region into war. But they are risky. A strike that kills a lot of people in either Israel or Lebanon would be enough to upset the balance. To make that less likely, Israel has evacuated around two dozen communities in the north, including Kiryat Shmona, a city of more than 20,000 people near the Lebanese border. Villages on the Lebanese side have also emptied as residents flee farther north.

Israel has hardened its border too: many reservists called up this month were sent north, not south. America has deployed two aircraft-carrier strike groups, one to the eastern Mediterranean, the other to the Persian Gulf. On October 21st it said it would deploy more Patriot air-defence battalions and a THAAD anti-ballistic missile battery. Another 2,000 troops are on standby for a possible deployment.

Israel's assessment is that these reinforcements have deterred Hizbullah from ramping up the fighting. Talk in the war cabinet of launching a pre-emptive strike on the group has died down. Of late, oil markets seem more sanguine, too. The price of Brent crude, which spiked from $85 a barrel before the Hamas attack to $92 on October 19th, has slipped to below $90.

Every Israeli war is fought watching the clock, as international condemnation grows and eventually America qualifies its support. In 1973 America urged a ceasefire ending the Yom Kippur War, even though Israeli forces were on the advance. In 2006 it imposed a ceasefire before Israel could achieve its objectives in Lebanon. As one Israeli official puts it, “Our window of international legitimacy is limited.”

The scenes of horror in Gaza mean the window is already closing. The UN says 1.4m people in the territory have been displaced; its shelters are crammed to two-and-a-half times their capacity. On October 13th Israel told the entire population of northern Gaza to flee south. Thousands who heeded that order have since travelled back the other way. If nowhere feels safe, they reckon, better to be in one's own home than a tent or a crowded shelter.

Israel refuses to allow any supplies to cross its border until Hamas releases all the hostages it holds captive. On October 21st the first shipment of aid, a convoy of 20 lorries containing food, water and medicine entered Gaza from Egypt. Several more deliveries followed. This is only a small fraction of what the territory needs (the UN says at least 100 lorries a day are required). Families have cut back to one meal a day. People have resorted to drinking salty water from wells. Aid workers say poor sanitation has led to cases of scabies and diarrhoea and fear that even more serious diseases will spread.

The World Health Organisation says six of Gaza's 13 hospitals have run out of fuel. Most bakeries are closed for the same reason; queues at those still working stretch up to six hours. Israel refuses to allow fuel shipments.

Arab states want an immediate ceasefire. The European Union is split, but Josep Borrell, its top diplomat, has called for a “humanitarian pause” to allow more supplies to enter. Rishi Sunak, Britain's prime minister, has signalled support for one too. America still offers Israel staunch backing, but will not do so indefinitely.

Yet Mr Netanyahu faces mounting pressure from his hard-right base to prove he is clobbering Hamas, and is loth to admit that Mr Biden or the hostages' families have stayed his hand. Instead, using proxies, he has begun to brief that the army is not ready for a ground campaign. Rather than risk soldiers' lives, it is argued, Israel should launch more devastating air strikes, including the use of bunker-busting bombs, to destroy Hamas's tunnel network.

The army has pushed back, saying it is “fully ready” for an invasion. There have been days of ugly but accurate headlines in the Israeli media about discord between Mr Netanyahu and his defence minister, Yoav Gallant. Mr Netanyahu tried to fire Mr Gallant in March, after the latter voiced criticism of the government's plan to weaken the supreme court. He was forced to retreat after massive public protests. There has been growing distrust between the two ever since, and it is now hampering Israel's war-planning effort.

On October 11th leaders of one opposition party, Benny Gantz and Gadi Eisenkot—both former army chiefs—joined the war cabinet. But they have failed to restore unity. “The [army] and the intelligence community were severely hit by their failure to detect and prevent the Hamas attack,” says a defence official. “But they've got back on their feet and are now just waiting for a clear idea from the government what to do.”

General confusion

The army's orders remain to destroy Hamas's military capabilities and end its control of Gaza. Some within the army and the wider defence establishment believe a more gradual ground campaign would be better. But generals were told to prepare for a broad offensive; they cannot change that plan unless the cabinet gives them a different timetable or a different goal. And the cabinet is dithering.

General Herzi Halevi, the army chief, has acknowledged the army's failure to prevent the massacre. So has Ronen Bar, the director of Shin Bet, Israel's internal-security service, and General Aharon Haliva, the head of military intelligence. All three are expected to do the honourable thing and resign after the war. Most Israelis want their prime minister to accept similar responsibility—but he has not.

Instead Mr Netanyahu spends most of his time huddling with political advisers and briefing journalists. He has assembled his own shadow cabinet of former generals and security officials to second-guess Mr Gallant and the army. “There are many who shoulder the blame for thinking that Hamas wouldn't dare do something like this,” says one Knesset member from Mr Netanyahu's coalition. “Obviously Bibi is more to blame than all the others, but don't wait for him to say so.”

Even a well-oiled government would struggle to navigate between so many competing priorities—and Israel, these days, barely has a government at all. ■

Israel is girding itself for a ground operation; violence in the West Bank is intensifying; and exchanges of missile and artillery fire between Israel and Hizbullah, a Lebanese Shia militia allied with Iran, presage a possible second front (see map).

On October 22nd Lloyd Austin, America's defence secretary, warned of the “prospect of a significant escalation” against American forces. American bases in Iraq and Syria have also been coming under attack by rockets and drones, presumably fired by other Iranian proxies. “This is the most dangerous moment since the cold war,” argues Matthew Kroenig of the Atlantic Council, a think-tank in Washington, DC . “If Iran and Hizbullah get involved, America may feel compelled to respond. And does China then see an opportunity to try something against Taiwan?”

President Joe Biden is thus turning into an unlikely wartime president. He was not exaggerating when he told Americans in a recent televised address that the world was at an inflection point. When America acted to help Ukraine resist Russia's invasion many asked whether it had the wherewithal to deter a looming Chinese assault against Taiwan. The question is all the more acute now that America also seeks to defend Israel. In Mr Biden's view, helping friends is not only possible but necessary. “American leadership is what holds the world together,” he declared. “American alliances are what keep us, America, safe.”

Yet academics debate whether and when the “unipolar” world, in which America bestrode the globe after the cold war, reverted to a “bipolar” one, in which America is challenged by China rather than the Soviet Union; or whether it is already a “multipolar” world. Joseph Nye, a Harvard academic, defined national power in three dimensions: military, economic and “soft power”, ie, the ability, among other things, to co-opt others to do your bidding.

In military terms, America remains a colossus (see chart). Economically, the world is bipolar in a way it never was during the cold war, with China's economic output somewhat smaller than America's at market exchange rates, and surpassing it at purchasing-power parity (though Americans remain far richer than Chinese). Soft power is harder to measure, but it is probably fair to say the world is more multipolar, says Mr Kroenig.

That said, in the Middle East, America is still the “indispensable nation”, a concept popularised by the late Madeleine Albright, a former secretary of state. It is the only country willing and able to mediate between regional leaders and shape events. That includes securing the opening of a (still inadequate) humanitarian corridor in Gaza. “The phone in Beijing didn't ring. The phone in Moscow didn't ring. But the phone in Washington has been ringing off the hook,” notes Ivo Daalder, formerly America's representative to NATO .

Set against that central role, though, is the fact that three Arab leaders—King Abdullah of Jordan, Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi, the Egyptian president, and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian one—have been frosty towards Mr Biden. He had been due to meet them in Amman on October 18th, after visiting Israel. But a day earlier a blast in the grounds of a Gaza hospital killed scores if not hundreds of Palestinians. Palestinians say the carnage was caused by an Israeli strike; Israel said it was the result of an errant Palestinian missile. Mr Biden seemed to give Israel the benefit of the doubt (and later said more firmly that it was not responsible). The Arab leaders did not. They cancelled the summit after Mr Abbas declared three days of mourning and returned home. Just then America looked like the dispensable power.

Not where he would start

In office, Mr Biden's priority has been revitalising the American economy. He borrowed the protectionist mindset of his predecessor, Donald Trump, and added large doses of subsidies and industrial policy to promote, among other things, green technology and the manufacture of semiconductors. Gratifyingly, the American economy has outperformed that of its rich-world peers. He hoped such policies would reduce social and political polarisation. He also hoped they would fortify America in its contest with China. Describing the era as one of “competition in an age of interdependence”, Mr Biden's national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, says foreign and domestic policies are more interconnected than ever, for instance in efforts to restrict China's access to advanced technology.

Abroad, Mr Biden sought to revitalise alliances that Mr Trump had either neglected or threatened to undo. He renewed the New START agreement with Russia, limiting long-range nuclear weapons, as part of his effort to establish “a stable, predictable relationship” with the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin.

Above all Mr Biden's foreign policy meant doing much less in the Middle East, a region that had consumed the energies of many an American president. He sought to end the “forever wars” in Iraq and Afghanistan. He promised to restore the nuclear deal with Iran, which Barack Obama had signed in 2015 and Donald Trump abandoned in 2018, to contain the danger of a nuclear Iran. He initially said Saudi Arabia should be treated as a “pariah”. He reverted to America's long-standing support for the “two-state solution”, ie, the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel, though he put little effort into it.

Much of this has gone awry for Mr Biden. Far from being stable and predictable, Mr Putin invaded Ukraine and information exchanges under New start are suspended. America's chaotic departure from Afghanistan allowed the Taliban to return to power instantly. In the Gulf, meanwhile, China took the plaudits for the restoration of diplomatic relations between Iran and Saudi Arabia, appearing to fill a vacuum left by American indifference.

Changing focus

Mr Biden flew to the Saudi city of Jeddah in July last year to make up with Muhammad bin Salman, the crown prince. The president could not persuade the de facto ruler of the world's biggest oil exporter to help moderate oil prices; instead, Saudi Arabia cleaved to a production deal with Russia to keep prices high. Moreover, he set a high bar for the normalisation of relations with Israel that Mr Biden hoped to bring about: concessions on the Palestinian question; a mutual-defence agreement with America; and uranium enrichment at home to counterbalance Iran's nuclear programme. Often Team Biden fell back on benign neglect. “The Middle East region is quieter today than it has been in two decades,” declared Mr Sullivan—just days before Hamas's onslaught.

America's allies around the world, especially in Asia, ask two seemingly contradictory questions, says Kori Schake of the American Enterprise Institute, an American think-tank. First, will American resources and attention be diverted to the Middle East? Second, will America's resolve in one or other crisis fail? “If we allow the security of Europe to be destabilised by Russian aggression, or allow Israel to suffer a terrible terrorist attack, they will believe that we don't care about any other problem,” she argues.

America's reliability as an ally comes down to both credibility and capacity. Given America's many alliances, academics have long debated the importance of credibility: does a failure to live up to obligations to one ally affect commitments to others? America's abandonment of the war in Vietnam, for instance, did not much damage its will to defend western Europe. The West went on to win the cold war.

These days the question is whether America's pell-mell departure from Afghanistan undermined American credibility and encouraged Russia to invade Ukraine. Tod Wolters, a former military commander of NATO forces, suggested last year that it had been one of several factors. But Mr Sullivan insists that, in fact, leaving Afghanistan “improved our strategic capacity” to respond to the invasion of Ukraine and the threat to Taiwan.

As for military capacity, America must supply weapons to Ukraine, Taiwan and now Israel. That raises doubts about whether its defence industries can meet their needs as well as its own. In general America sends different weapons to the three countries, but some demands overlap. For instance, 155mm artillery shells are in short supply, and America is reported to have diverted a consignment intended for Ukraine to Israel. The war in Ukraine has shown how big state-on-state conflicts consume vast quantities of munitions. War games suggest that, in a war over Taiwan, America would quickly run out of the long-range anti-ship missiles that would be most useful in repelling a Chinese invasion of Taiwan.

Such problems can be solved with time and money, but both are in short supply because of America's polarisation and congressional paralysis. Republicans, especially those of Mr Trump's “America First” tendency, have grown ever more sceptical about supporting Ukraine in its war. And Congress, unable to pass bills since the removal of the speaker of the House of Representatives, Kevin McCarthy, on October 3rd, got a new one, Mike Johnson, only this week.

Mr Biden hopes cross-party sympathy for Israel will unblock things. He has asked Congress for a massive $106bn in supplemental national-security spending. He seeks to pre-empt future divisive votes on Ukraine by allocating $61bn in military and economic aid to the country, to tide it through America's febrile 2024 election season. To make it more palatable, he has wrapped it in other spending that Republicans should find more appealing, including $14bn for Israel; $2bn for military-equipment transfers in the Indo-Pacific (probably to Taiwan); nearly $12bn in various measures to strengthen the processing of migrants on the southern border; and $3bn for the submarine defence-industrial base.

In defending Israel, America is backing a country that breaches international law by building Jewish settlements in occupied territories, rejects statehood for Palestinians and stands accused of imposing collective punishments on Palestinians, if not committing war crimes, in its bombardment and siege of Gaza.
